characters: INT, GRAND BALLROOM, ST. JAMES HOTEL
EXT, PORCH, HOUSE ON THE HILL, (FLASHBACK)
I HAVE KILLED JESSE JAMES. BOB FORD

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: He was growing into middle age and was living then in a bungalow on Woodland Avenue. Green weeds split the porch steps, a wasp nest clings to gable, a rope swing loops down from a dying elm tree and below it is scuffed soft as flour.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: He installed himself in a rocking chair and smoked a cigar down in the evening as his wife wiped her pink hands on an apron and reported happily on their two children. INT. WOODLAND AVE. COTTAGE - DAY. Action as per voice over:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: Whenever he walked about the house, he carried several newspapers — the Sedalia Daily democrat, the St. Joseph Gazette, and the Kansas City Times ~ each with a foot-long .44 caliber pistol tucked into a fold. EXT. STREET, KANSAS CITY - DAY. JESSE, from a distance, a dandy in his gentleman’s clothe Everyone seems to know him.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: He went everywhere unrecognized and lunched with Kansas City shopkeepers and merchants, calling himself a cattleman or commodities investor, someone rich and leisured who had the common touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSE'S scars and wounds:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He had two incompletely healed bullet. holes in his chest and another in his thigh. He was missing the nub of his left middle finger and was cautious lest that mutilation be seen. EXT. WOODLAND AVE. BACKYARD - DUSK. JESSE looks out beyond the prairie wheat, to the dying s

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: He also had a condition that was referred to as granulated eyelids and it caused him to blink more than usual, as if he found creation slightly more than he could accept. EXT. GARDEN PATCH - DAY. He scours for nightcrawlers and flips them into manure pa them into writhing sections and sprinkles them over his g

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: He could neither multiply nor divide without error and much of his science was superstition. He could list the many begotten of Abraham and the sixty-six books of the king James Bible; he could recite psalms and poems in a stentorian voice with suitable histrionics; he could sing religious hymns so convincingly that he once worked as a choirmaster; he was marvelously informed about current events. MONTAGE: JESSE'S beliefs.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: And yet he thought incense was made from the bones of saints, Bones are ground.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: -that leather continued to grow if not dyed, Leather grows.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0O)
dialogues.text: -that if he concentrated hard enough his body’s electrical currents could stun lake frogs as he bathed. A frogs keels over. JESSE watches:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: He could be reckless or serene, rational or lunatic, from one minute to the next. INT. DRYGOODS STORE, KANSAS CITY - DAY. Action as per voiceover:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: If he made an entrance, heads turned in his direction; if he strode down an aisle storeclerks backed away;  EXT. STREET, KANSAS CITY - DAY. A dog shies, its hackles raised.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: iff he neared animals they retreated. INT. TOPEKA EXCHANGE SALOON, KANSAS CITY. DAY. CUSTOMERS become disturbed, affected without knowing why. NARRATOR (V/O) . Rooms seemed hotter when he was in them, RAINFALL, as seen through a window:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: rains fell straighter,

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: clocks slowed, CUTLERY clatters:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: sounds were amplified: ON JESSE as he slowly lifts a flaming hand:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0O)
dialogues.text: His enemies would not have been much surprised if he produced horned owls from beer bottles or made candles out of his fingers. EXT. WOODLAND AVE. BACKYARD - DAY. He wades barefoot through the backyard grass with his six hunched on his shoulders and his trousers rolled up to hi

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0O)
dialogues.text: He considered himself a Southern loyalist and guerrilla in a Civil War that never ended. He regretted neither his robberies nor the seventeen murders that he laid claim to,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSE, sleepless, at the kitchen table:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: -but he would brood about his slanders and slights, his callow need for attention, his overweening vaingloriousness, and he was excessively genteel and polite in order to disguise what he thought was vulgar, primitive, and depraved in his origins.  EXT. PRAIRIE. DUSK. JESSE in the prairie wheat at dusk.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: Sicknesses made him smell blood each morning, he visited rooms at night, he sometimes heard children in the fruit cellar, he waded into prairie wheat and stared at the horizon. CLOSE on JESSE, his eyes impossibly blue:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: He had seen another summer under in Kansas City, Missouri, and on September 5%, in the year 1881, he was thirty-four years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty feet below is a cinder roadbed, the sickle curve o grade that is hard work for a locomotive. Beyond that is ridge - a lower elevation - rising ten feet above the cut EXT. SOUTHERN RIDGE - DAY. FRANK JAMES (stern, 38) stands back in the green darkness terrain. Off-screen we hear the sound of some fool crashi weeds to the rear of him. FRANK opens his coat and slides his revolver.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (OFF-SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but I see I’ve sort of traipsed in and interrupted you. FRANK turns to see a boy in a stovepipe hat and an overla that’s cinched by a low-slung holster. His hands are over gun is upon him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Which one are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob Ford.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Ah, Charley's brother. BOB receives this as an invitation to lower his hands. He next to FRANK and takes off his hat.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I was lying when I said I just happened down here. I’ve been looking for you. I feel lousy that I didn’t say so at the outset. FRANK digs in his pockets and extracts cigarette makings inclined to converse.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Folks sometimes take me for a nincompoop on account of the shabby first impression I make, whereas I’ve always thought of myself as being just a rung down from the James brothers. And, well, I was hoping if’I ran into you aside from those peckerwoods, I could show you how special I am. I honestly believe I’m destined for great things, Mr. James. I’ve got qualities that don’t come shining through right at the outset, but give me a chance and I'll get the job done - I can guarantee you that. FRANK slimes his cigarette and strikes a match off his bo BOB slaps He stands

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You’re not so special Mr. Ford. You’re just like any other tyro who’s prinked himself up for an escapade. You’re hoping to be a gunslinger like those nickel books are about, but you may as well quench your mind of it. You don’t have the ingredients. a mosquito and looks at his blood freckled palm.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to hear you feel that way since I put such stock in your opinions. and rehats himself.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: As for me being a gunslinger, I’ve just got this one granddaddy Patterson Colt and a borrowed belt to stick it in. But I've also got an appetite for greater things. I hoped joining up with you would put me that much closer to getting them. And that’s the plain and simple truth of the matter.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: So what do you want me to say?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You'll let me be your sidekick tonight. Sidekick?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: So you can examine my grit and intelligence. FRANK examines his cigarette, sucks it once more, and fli roadbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t know what it is about you, but the more you talk, the more you give me the willies. I don’t believe I even want you as close as earshot this evening.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I‘m sorry-

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Why don’t you go? And, after a beat, BOB tramps up the hill, slapping weeds EXT. WOODS. (MOVING WITH BOB TO THE GANG’S CAMP) DAY. BOB passes a number of horses reined to a piece of rope f two trees. He passes MEN aged in their late teens and ear hooligans mainly, boys with vulgar features and sullen ey cradle shotguns and wear patched coveralls and foul looki They are known collectively as THE CRACKERNECK BOYS and a to provide ‘atmosphere’ at the robbery and easy prey for afterwards. BOB clears this group and arrives to a view o surrounded by the inner gang; the current apostles: ROBERT WOODSON HITE (WOOD) is JESSE'S cousin, sulking and some imagined slight. CHARLEY FORD is BOB’S older brother, who chuckles and bra haws and who covers his left boot with a coat in order to clubfoot. DICK LIDDIL and ED MILLER can be seen in the background, cast iron pot: MILLER is the anxious type; has a streak of spit where hi ought to be. DICK LIDDIL is a good-looking horse-thief. BOB eyes this group hungrily, coveting admission. He then ground just as DICK LIDDIL rattles the pot and sings out:

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Chowtime! JESSE is the last to rise, and BOB closes in on him like

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Am I too late to wish you a happy birthday?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: How'd you know?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised at what I've got stored away. I'm an authority on the James boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name isn’t Bunny Ford, is it? BOB begins to nod, then checks himself:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Why no. It’s Robert Ford.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Of course it is.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Bob.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You've never been with the gang before, have you?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh no sirree. I'ma virgin. At least in that one respect, if you get my meaning. JESSE takes a heaped bowl from DICK LIDDIL in his gunnysa lowers himself onto a stump and BOB squats in the dirt at

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Your brother Frank and I just had a real nice visit. Must’ve been a hundred subjects entertained, having to do with the Chicago and Alton Railroad and the assignments on board the cars. JESSE, bored, closes his eyes and exercises a crick in hi

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, the upshot was, we sort of mutually agreed that I should use my abilities as your helper and, you know, apprentice. So we could be confederates together and come out of this unscathed. That was the upshot. JESSE opens his eyes and squints at BOB.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well, Buck does the figuring. Do you know what this stew needs, Bob? BOB is perplexed:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Dumplings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noodles. You eat yourself some noodle stew and your clock will tick all night. You ever see that woman over in Fayette could suck noodles up her nose?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Don’t believe I have.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You've got canals in your head you never dreamed of. BOB is dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don’t like to harp on a subject but-

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don’t care who comes with me. Never have. I’m what they call gregarious. FRANK JAMES is drinking coffee and scowling as he sits on of the fire. JESSE raises his voice:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I hear you and young Stovepipe here had a real nice visit. FRANK looks askance at BOB and flings the dregs of his co ground.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (terse) Your boys have got about an acre of rock to haul, Dingus. You'd better goose them down yonder. EXT. BLUE CUT RAILBED - DAY. A cotton wood tree is skidded down the bank and heaved ov polished steel rails. The CRACKERNECK BOYS carry boulders sandstone which they fort around the tree as shovels sing splinter. JESSE supervises the rock piling, recommending mined for stone, chewing his green cigar black. Shadows grow long and die. Clouds brick overhead and brin crimson. Then violet. Then black. EXT. NORTHERN RIDGE - NIGHT. BOB holds a match for JESSE as he reads the dial of a poc

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You can stick with me but don’t heel. I don’t want to bust into you every time I have the notion to change direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I‘m not a moron, for Heaven's sake. JESSE curtains his coat halves over his revolvers.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: They’re supposed to have a hundred thousand dollars in that express car; at least that’s what the gossip is.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: My fingers are already starting to itch. JESSE squats and strikes a match and turns up the flame o He then wads a red flannel sleeve around the glass chimne yellow light rubies. FRANK calls from above:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (OFFSCREEN)
dialogues.text: That‘s ideal. EXT. SOUTHERN RIDGE - NIGHT. FRANK is up on the South Ridge with DICK LIDDIL, WOOD HIT and CHARLEY FORD. He watches the CRACKERNECK BOYS who ram lackadaisically along the tracks, rifles hoisted, dangero paths with each other in the night.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Look at those fools. They’re going to trip and shoot each other into females.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I‘1l bet I can find them husbands if they do. This jollies even FRANK. EXT. NORTHERN RIDGE. NIGHT. JESSE holds the lantern over his pocket watch. Both hands

dialogues.speaker: JESSE '
dialogues.text: About two years ago we robbed the same . railroad, only it was right in Glendale we boarded her.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I know that. You might not realize it yet but I’m a storehouse of information about the James gang. I mean I’ve followed your careers. BOB stuffs a white handkerchief under his stovepipe hat s conceals his face. (One eyehole has been cut slightly low other - creating the impression that he is cock-eyed and at all what he had mind.)  10

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Do you know what happened five years ago to the day? To the day? What happened on September seventh in eighteen seventy-six?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You made an attempt on a Northfield, Minnesota, bank. Wasn’t it owned by General Ben Butler? The Scourge of New Orleans?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Knew it.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Bill Chadwell, Clell Miller, Charlie Pitts - they were killed outright. The Youngers have been in prison ever since. It’s painful to recall.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: And you never got a plug nickel from that bank.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So you can see how this date would have an aroma for me. Then JESSE pricks up likes an animal might. EXT. BLUE CUT RAILBED - NIGHT. He hops down the bank in three plunging steps, shakes out cuffs, and keels to put his ear to the rails. The hum of locomotive is like insects in a jar.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: She's right on schedule, Buck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK stubs out his cigarette and turns to DICK. .

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You'd better go on down to Jesse. EXT. BLUE CUT RAILBED - NIGHT. JESSE raises the blue bandana over his nose and places hi on the rail as DICK slides down the southern cliff. DICK bandana over his face and ambles over, shaking the dust f The locomotive’s chuffing is growing loud. JESSE'S right foot tickles with rail vibrations.  11 The headlamp’s aisle of white light fills the forest pass across scrub and bush, then bends and floods toward JESSE his red-lantern in a yard master’s signal to stop. The br engaged with an ear splitting scream. Couplings bang. Spa the rails as the engine swiftly decelerates. And a great breaks over JESSE. Then the GANG is running and bounding and skidding down t embankments. BOB FORD slides down like a debutante in petticoats, his snatching at roots while his right unveils his eyes long around at the commotion: MEN rush alongside the train levering their rifles in a m fancy is ghoulish and frightening. JESSE hops out of the steam and up onto the cab step and revolver. The ENGINEER cringes down behind his hands:

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEER
dialogues.text: Don’t shoot! Ain’t no call for that!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You two best come down from your machine and bring a coal pick along.

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEER
dialogues.text: You’ve got the gun. He obediently drops a coal pick onto the cinderbed and cl STOKER follows - he’s scared sick, sweat crawls over the face. He looks about sixteen. JESSE shakes the hands of b

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I’m Jesse James; the man you’ve read so much about. EXT. BAGGAGE/EXPRESS CAR - NIGHT. The BAGGAGEMASTER and EXPRESS MESSENGER have their heads door at radically different heights. t

dialogues.speaker: BAGGAGEMASTER
dialogues.text: Opie? We’re going to bolt this door from the inside.

dialogues.speaker: EXPRESS MESSENGER
dialogues.text: I’d say that’s a good idea. The door slams. INT. BAGGAGE/EXPRESS CAR - NIGHT. The two men stack chicken coops, bags and boxes to hide t Express Company safe.  12

dialogues.speaker: BAGGAGEMASTER
dialogues.text: If they push you to the brink, do what you must to save your own skin.

dialogues.speaker: EXPRESS MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Thanks for the reminder. The MESSENGER leans himself against the doorframe and pee crack. He sees: A man in a confederate officer’s coat and blue bandana ma toward the express section with the young STOKER in tow. young boy in a stovepipe hat points the ENGINEER in the s with his revolver. EXT. BAGGAGE/EXPRESS CAR - NIGHT. The ENGINEER tries the doorknob. Then tries again with hi behind it.

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEER
dialogues.text: It's locked. JESSE re-cocks his revolver.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you smash it in. The ENGINEER grunts the coal pick up and swings it into t the latch. The wood splinters loudly. He has to tug hard the embedded spike.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (to BOB) The locked doors and the smashing them down, that’s a little skit we run through each time — sort of like grace before dinner. The ENGINEER swings again: INT. BAGGAGE/EXPRESS CAR - SAMETIME. The wood screams and folds inward from the blow. The MESS that they'll get in anyway and goes for the bolts:

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: All right! All right! you can come in now! JESSE socks the door open, heaves his chest onto the thre knees himself into the room. DICK LIDDIL, ED MILLER and t CHARLEY FORD follow him. A lantern is passed up as JESSE and shakes them and guesses at their contents:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That’s a woman’s satchel; all fancy bead work and paper flowers.  13

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: (nervous grin) Could be. JESSE smashes another box on a nail and snags it open, fi photograph of a child in an oval frame, the cheek torn by looks at it a moment and then glares at the frightened ME

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I want you to open that safe. The MESSENGER looks to the BAGGAGEMASTER for council - bu head is down. He looks back at JESSE with his nervous smi FORD steps forward and strikes him over the skull with hi man drops to his knees, blood shoelacing his face. The BA backs to wall in horror.

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: You didn’t have to bop him, Charley.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yes, he did. They need the convincing. They got their company rules and I got my mean streak and that’s how we get things done. CHARLEY grins with accomplishment and JESSE clears some r the only safe he can see.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Come over here and attend to this now. We hear a wild and scrambled off-screen fusillade and DIC outside to see what’s going on: - NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CRACKERNECKS are firing at TWO FIGURES crouching with lantern. FRANK JAMES hollers for them to cease, and after twenty rounds they do. DICK sees BOB FORD squatting in the weeds, standing guard STOKER and ENGINEER, his cocked revolver up next to his c

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: (calling) Scare ya? BOB stands sheepishly:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I couldn’t tell what on earth was going on! INT. BAGGAGE/EXPRESS CAR - NIGHT. The EXPRESS MESSENGER jerks the company vault door open. empties the contents of the safe into a grain sack which JESSE. JESSE puzzles over it’s contents.  14

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Isn’t no hundred thousand dollars in here, Dick. DICK looks into the grain sack:

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I’m real disappointed. JESSE turns on the EXPRESS MESSENGER:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Get down on your knees.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You oughta pray; I’m going to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: (panic) Hey?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Get down!

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: You’1l have to make me.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: All right. JESSE socks the man with his pistol and he drops like emp JESSE looks at him for a moment, then cocks his pistol an against the unconscious man’s head. ED MILLER reacts with

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: Don’t shoot him! JESSE grins, uncocks the pistol, and picks up the grain s

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Don’t you tell me what I can and can’t do. EXT. BLUE CUT RAILBED - NIGHT. BOB FORD, standing over the ENGINEER and the STOKER, watc jumps down from the EXPRESS CAR. JESSE encourages the MES BAGGAGEMASTER outside with his gun. The MESSENGER stagger BOB, bleeding profusely, and crashes down into the weeds. the wound in panic.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: We’re going to go through the cars. If any of them so much as twitch, give their coconuts a sockdolager: that’s a language they understand.  15 INT. PASSENGER CAR - NIGHT. WOOD HITE’S boot slams the door aside, and he enters, an flour sack over his head, his twelve-gauge thrust forward

dialogues.speaker: WOOD HITE
dialogues.text: Throw up your hands, you sons-a-bitches! And for emphasis he slaps a MAN in the mouth. Then FRANK JAMES enters in his gray coat and yellow banda He sees thirty MEN either cowering or flinching or accusi their eyes, while the WIVES scrunch down behind their hus shoulders. He strides down the aisle, imperious as Victoria’s consor bootheels barking on the oakwood flooring. He scowls and any who seem recalcitrant, ticking a button or collar wit Remington revolver.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Are any of you preachers? No one raises a hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Are any of you widows? Some frown with curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We never rob preachers or widows. Four hands shoot up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No; no, you’re too late. FRANK nods to the rear of the coach and JIM CUMMINS scutt and punches his revolver into the into the coat of a man.

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUMMINS
dialogues.text: I'm Jesse James, ya damned yellow dog! Gimme all your money! The MAN fiddles in his coat and produces a worn envelope and an English gold watch. A bearded man with spectacles hands FRANK JAMES a roll of FRANK has a hunch about him and puts a cocked revolver to

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Delve a little deeper. The man turns up a further hundred dollars. JESSE raps on the doorglass with his gun. Frank swivels a in. DICK and CHARLEY follow.  16

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Just work your way to the middle. The GANG make their way down the coach with sacks, steali dollars, watches, bracelets, rings, stickpins, pendants. Children wail in corners, several women have become hyste Men sit in chairs with blank faces, their hands lumped in having lost fortunes; their crabbed savings, the cost of auction sale of six Holstein cows, a laggard Silver Anniv EXT. PASSENGER CAR PLATFORM - LATER. A dispirited JESSE exits onto the platform where he sees of the others shedding loot into a flour sack. WOOD HITE pass by him with fire axes. A young BRAKEMAN sits nearby bankrupt.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: How much did you lose?

dialogues.speaker: BRAKEMAN
dialogues.text: Fifty cents and that was all I had. JESSE digs into his grain sack and hands the BRAKEMAN a d

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Here‘s the principal and interest on your money. . The sound of wood splintering is heard and JESSE turns to and ED MILLER attacking the bedding and boxes in the slee The whole affair degenerating into a carousal. JESSE shou

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay! Enough! Let’s vamoose! EXT. SOUTHERN RIDGE - NIGHT. The gang scrabble up the bank to the woods. We follow BOB CHARLEY waits with the gathered horses. BOB removes his m cut out eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I was in top form tonight. Did you see me roast that one gent for standing on his cash?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No. I missed that. I was outside, y’see.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: He kind of skidded when he walked was how I knew. And his wife, she was in a state, her beady little eyes all squinched up.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Really took the cake, did she?  17

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Oh my, yes. Jesse's gonna be satisfied with me. EXT. NEARBY CORNFIELD - NIGHT. JESSE’S horse prances impatiently as he removes a documen shirt and displays it for the assembled GANG:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: This here is a proclamation by the governor of Missouri. (beat, he glares for effect) It mentions Glendale and how certain parties confederated to steal what was on that train. It goes on about the Winston shebang last summer and then it says that the governor, one Thomas T. Crittenden, is offering a reward of five thousand dollars for the arrest and delivery of Frank James or Jesse James to the sheriff of Daviess County. It goes on to offer a further reward of five thousand dollars for our conviction of either of these crimes. The governor has a regular toothache over the James gang. My guess is hhe‘ll agree to just about anything thing if it‘ll make the pain go away. (beat) But you won’t none of you get away with bargaining or making exchanges. I’ve got a wife and two children I‘ve got to look out for.

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: You can trust me. Jesse rocks back and gives himself over to a long thought replying:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know I can, Ed. EXT. KANSAS CITY, OUTSKIRTS - NIGHT. The JAMES the FORD BROTHERS and WOOD HITE ride into KANSA cold rain that knuckles their hats and sinks their horses mire. INT. WOODLAND AVE. COTTAGE - NIGHT. ZEE JAMES is asleep on the sofa. JESSE creaks open the ki surprises her awake with a kiss. INT. WOODLAND AVE. KITCHEN - NIGHT. ZEE boils water.  18

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I was at a cattle auction in Independence. Had a good day too. She doesn’t look up from the saucepan.

dialogues.speaker: ZEE
dialogues.text: So you’ve got money again?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Come out of it real satisfactory. He jumps up from his chair and ganders out at the red bar sit still.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Guess who I ran into? She gives JESSE a wifely look and removes a jar from the

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Buck, for one. Then Wood Hite and two coves of his. They’re with the animals right now.

dialogues.speaker: ZEE
dialogues.text: They do satisfactory at the auction, too?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (grins) About the most they ask is that they come out of a swap meet with all their fingers and toes. He adjusts a dry hat on his head, and then, without justi exit, heads out to the stables. INT. BARN. WOODLAND AVE - NIGHT. Coal-oil lanterns gladden the interior of the barn, but F gloomy and glaring at the younger men’s slipshod manageme horses. He sees JESSE appear at the Dutch door and grumpi himself on a long bench, his legs wide, his fingers joine yellow cigarette. The JAMES brothers do not speak. EXT. BARN. WOODLAND AVE - NIGHT. JESSE stands just inside the sloshing eave peering at his with melancholy. It’s a moment before he perceives that B standing to his right.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You must’ve creeped up on cat’s paws.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'll wager that’s the first and last time you'll ever be caught off-guard.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: How old are you, kid?  19

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Twenty. (beat) Except I won’t really be twenty until January. (He scratches his sleeve apologetically.) I’m nineteen.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You feel older than that though, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yes, I do.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You enjoy yourself this evening?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I was strung too high for much pleasure. JESSE seems to think this an appropriate remark.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Do you like tea? INT. BARN. WOODLAND AVE. - LATER. FRANK gathers two horse blankets and makes his way to an

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Do you think the sheriff's out already?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Generally is. CHARLEY slinks over to the stall and watches as the grim coat.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I wasn’t just flapping my lips about my kid brother and me. What I figured was if you and Jesse could gauge our courage and daring, you just might make us your regular sidekicks. FRANK shoots him a look of umbrage as he spreads out a wo the straw.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You're beginning to sound like Bob.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I‘1l be square with you: it was Bob who put me up to it. He’s got plans for the James boys that I can’t even get the hang of, they’re that complicated. FRANK settles into repose, wrapping another horse blanket  20

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You might as well forget everything about that because there’1l be no more monkey business after tonight. You can jot it down in your diary: September seventh, eighteen eighty-one; the James gang robbed one last train at Blue Cut and gave up their nightriding for good.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: How will you make your living? FRANK is smoking a cigarette with his eyes shut.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Maybe I’‘1l sell shoes. EXT. WOODLAND AVE. PORCH - NIGHT. JESSE and BOB come out onto the porch with a candle and t JESSE lowers into a rocker and BOB takes the mating chair forward over the flame and lights his cigar.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I can’t believe I woke up this morning wondering if my Daddy would loan me his overcoat, and here it is just past midnight and I’ve already robbed a railroad and I’m sitting in a rocking chair chatting with none other than Jesse James.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It‘s a wonderful world.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Have you ever heard outlaws call dollar bills ‘Williams’? I read that in Morrison’s Sensational Series. You see, Bill is a nickname for William.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: . BOB
dialogues.text: You haven't heard anybody say it though?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Can’t say so.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You know what I’ve got right next to my bed? The Trainrobbers, or a story of the James Boys, by R. W. Stevens. Many’s the night I’ve stayed up with my mouth open and my eyes jumping out, reading about your escapades in the wide Awake Library.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: They're all lies, you know.  21°

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: ‘Course they are.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to keep smoking that if it’s making you bungey. BOB is relieved. He reaches over the banister and drops t puddle. JESSE smiles: JESSE . You know what Charley once told me about you? He said you had a shoebox practically filled with James boys mementoes. BOB submerges his resentment.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: That must have been a couple of years ago.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Or maybe it was Bunny who did that.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You’re making sport of me, aren’t you. JESSE catches BOB‘S wrist and puts a finger to his lips: with a lunchpail tramps through the rainmuck of the stree

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (calling out) Evening, Chas!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: They’ve got you working late again!

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: James ,gang robbed another train.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You don‘t mean it! (calling after him) If they put a posse together get me into it, will ya? The man crosses the street to his yard.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You really are the cool customer they make you out to be. I’m impressed as all get-out. JESSE seems suddenly glum.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I’m a no good, Bob. I ain’t Jesus.  22 JESSE gets up, goes back inside the bungalow, and closes FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK JAMES and family are assembled in traveling clothes PHAETON CARRIAGE. ZEE hugs ANNIE RALSTON JAMES and then g old ROB to her bosom. FRANK receives her kiss like medici turns to the backyard to see his younger brother angrily

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB watches from the Kitchen window as the Phaeton pulls drops his cup in the sink and heads out to the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSE sits in a rocker that is submerged to its seat in g weeds. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: My brother and me, we’re scarcely on speaking terms these days.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I wasn’t going to mention it. JESSE reaches into a tin under his chair and hauls up two snakes. BOB flinches. :

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You scared?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Just surprised a little.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: They aren't as succulent as I like and they’re the devil to clean but if a man skins them and fries them in garlic and oil - mercy, it’s good eating.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’ve never been that hungry. JESSE unfolds a four-inch knife and lifts the head of a s blade.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I give them names.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Such as enemies. I give them the names of enemies.  23 ~~ He lays the snakes on the arm of his chair and careful heads with his knife. The bodies curl and thrash. He flic into the grass.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Go tell Wood and Charley to get their gatherings together.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Me too?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You can stay. INT. BARN, WOODLAND AVE. - DAY. The dismissal hits WOOD hard: wooD I’m his cousin! My momma was his daddy’s--?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Sister. WwOooD That’s right! So how come it’s me who has to rattle his hocks out of town? CHARLEY is already packing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “ If I know Jess, there’s some real nasty sad- suzie work that’s got to be done around here and Bob's the ninny that has to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they exit JESSE is at the compost crib, drooling the onto the mulch.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE '
dialogues.text: Wood? You tell your daddy I’'1l be in Kentucky in October and maybe we can hunt some birds together. wooD But how come it’s Bob who gets to stay?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Bob’s going to move my gear to a house down. the street. CHARLEY winks at his brother.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: See.  24

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don’t mind, (though of course he does) Sounds like an adventure. CHARLEY jumps up onto his mare and addresses JESSE:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: If you ever need me to make smoke someplace again, a body can usually find-me at my sister’s - over at the Harbison homestead.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I’ll keep it in mind. wooD You know where I’'1l be. JESSE limps over to the bungalow.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It’s been pleasant. At the porch door he gives BOB an exacting look which imp already beginning to suspect his own judgment.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You've got some packing to do, kid.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: They moved to 1017 Troost Avenue at night so that the neighborhood couldn't get a good look at them or their belongings. BOB is does all the lifting, JESSE provides direction. NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) And then Bob thought Jesse would give him eight hours sleep and a daydreaming goodbye;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FAMILY are assembled around the dining table. BOB see hoping his continued presence wont be noticed.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ~but with a second day in the J.T. Jackson house, Bob thought he might never go but might be brought in as a good-natured cousin to the boy and a gentleman helper to Zee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Action as per voice-over:  25 NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) He curried the horse next to the horse that Jesse curried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Action as per voice-over:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He smoked a cigar that matched the cigar that Jesse smoked. They rocked in chairs on the front porch-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Action as per voice-over: NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) -and made trips to the Topeka Exchange saloon, where Jesse could spend nearly sixty minutes sipping one glass of beer and still complain about feeling tipsy.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bob would rarely vouchsafe his opinions as they talked. If spoken to, he would fidget and grin;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSE chats with a man in the street. Move in on BOB. NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) if Jesse palavered with another person, Bob secretaried their dialogue, getting each inflection, reading every gesture and tick, as if he wanted to compose a biography of the outlaw, or as if he were preparing an impersonation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSE wades in the shallows with his trousers rolled. BOB nannies TIM on the steep bank. A fire burns next to t JESSE sloshes up the cliff and looks down at the fishing

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Any nibbles?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Can't say I’ve felt even a twitch, Jess.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (cautions: ) Little rabbits have big ears, Bob.  26

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Dave. Could be it’s not night enough yet, Dave. JESSE turns to the boy:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You want to go play? TIM slides down the weeds without saying, going down to t father had walked in. JESSE unlids a mason jar and hands swallows, spilling beer on his chin.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Good?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Good as baby Jesus in velvet pants. JESSE scowls at the blasphemy.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Your people God-fearing, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh heavenly days, yes. My daddy’s a part-time preacher.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Rich or poor? BOB thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Prosperous, I guess. He could give me plenty of money but he’s got this philosophy that his boys ought to feel some hardships or else they’1l spoil.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: A man of principles. '

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: People say that when really they only want to make you unhappy. TIM swats the river with a washed-up board. JESSE calls t

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Don’t get yourself all soaked now you little honyock. JESSE starts putting on his socks and boots.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You ever hear any gossip about my father and Frank’s being two different men?  27

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: They say that was the reason my papa went West in the Gold Rush: he couldn’t support the shame of it. What do you think of a story like that?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’m more personally interested in what you think of it.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (angry) I think it’s a goddamned lie.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’m with you then; and I won’t hear another word on it if the subject ever comes up. BOB removes his hat and scratches his head.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Since we're telling stories, have you heard the one about the James gang robbing the railroad?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You‘re not giving me enough clues.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It’s a funny story. JESSE shakes his head and takes another drink.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You see, the James gang is robbing this railroad train like you do, and on board is this Quaker minister, some old coot with a long beard and a mean disposition. He’s got this pinched-up wife with him and she’s shivering with fright and clutching his i sleeve. You sure you haven't heard this? .

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I would have stopped you by now.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: How’s it go? I’ve gotta get this right. Oh! I guess it’s you: You stand in this railroad coach and you holler, ‘I’m Jesse James! And here’s what I‘m gonna do! I'm gonna grab all your money. I’m gonna grab all your jewelry! I‘m gonna grab everything you own! The Ppreacher’s wife is cringing now, and cowering behind the old coot and you say, ‘And then I’m gonna go down the aisle and rape all you women! ‘

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t like the way this story’s headed.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, everyone knows it’s not true, Jess; it’s just sort of comical. Anyway, the Quaker ups and says, ‘Surely you wouldn’t rape a preacher’s wife!’ And the wife gives him an elbow and says, ‘Shut up, Homer! It’s Jesse's train. Let him rob it the way he wants to.’ JESSE isn’t laughing.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You don’t think it’s funny?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well, hell, how could I if it isn’t true?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Jokes don’t need to be, Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You‘’re gonna have to explain why I oughta laugh then.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (impatient) Why don't we just forget it. (then, scared:) I didn’t mean to sound sharp just then. JESSE adjusts his jacket sleeves.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I've got a story for you that’s true as a razor. This’1l give you an example of putting aman in his place, and it don’t depend upon any prevaricating. Once me and Frank were riding in the countryside and got hungry, so we went up to this farmhouse and asked would this widow lady make us some supper.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh, that one.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You've heard it?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Only about twenty times. JESSE is as still as a shut-down machine.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’d love the chance to hear you tell it, though. I imagine you’ll make it more interesting.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: ‘I‘1l gladly pay you,’ I say, and she said that was all right, we looked like genuine Christians and she’d do us the good turn. Kid, I want to tell you, that was one scrumptious supper. She went all out. But Frank saw she was crying and when he asked why, she said the mortgage was coming due and that the loan manager was going to be there any minute to repossess the Place. And her a poor Widow! Can you imagine? Well now, Frank and me, we insist on paying her something; and you know what we gave her?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Enough to pay off the mortgage.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You have heard this one.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: But no one ever said the supper was scrumptious. This is fascinating.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So we gave her what she needed and we go, and on the highway who‘s coming our way but the loan manager. He greets us but doesn’t give Frank and me a second thought, he’s that greedy to get hold of that farm. Much to his surprise, of course, she paid him off and in no time he was plodding along the road with his wallet bulging his coat out and his grin on a little tighter. And that’s when Frank and me come out of the woods with masks on and steal all our money back! JESSE laughs uproariously, slapping his thigh like a Plow

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: And you're saying that’s a true story.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Is!

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Jesse!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (testy) You calling me a liar? TIM crawls back up from the river and plops down in his f He throws a rock and the river glunks.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Don't do that, son. You’1ll scare all the fishes away.  30

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Daddy, I’m boring.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (laughs) You mean, you're bored.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes. JESSE hugs the boy to him:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Maybe a fish will come and get you all excited. Tm I don’t like fishing.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Sure you do. I do. You must. The boy sinks into his father’s jacket. The river is the

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You know what we are, Tim? We’re nighthawks. We're the ones who go out at night and guard everything so people can sleep in peace. We’ve got our eyes peeled; no one’s going to slip anything past us.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’ve got something!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It’s heavy! JESSE sidles next to him and clearly struggles with the t seize the pole from BOB’S grip.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Don‘t horse it, kid. Bring it up easy. BOB steps on the bamboo pole and hauls the weight up with The catch is heaved onto the river bank: It's a gruesome prehistoric thing that seems overdue for extinction. Roun with feelers that move like thumbs on its skull. TIM back father’s leg.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: God damn it, but that’s an ugly thing. Its teeth mesh and unmesh with a click. Its gill wings un is disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Kill him, kid. BOB takes a burning stick from the fire and stabs it into and over again.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That's enough! JESSE glares at BOB, as though he’s been given a sign and accordingly.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0O)
dialogues.text: Bob was sent away the next day as he knew he would be. EXT. STORE, LIBERTY - DAY. NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) And it was already noon by the time he attained Liberty. BOB waters his horse at a trough. He sinks a dipper into And, as he raises it, he catches sight of his reflection: NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) Here, he viewed himself in a store window and was discouraged by the reflection: A scroungy boy in a ridiculous stovepipe hat. He thought himself goofy and juvenile. INT. STORE, LIBERTY ~ DAY. BOB cruises the aisles: Prince Albert suits; greatcoats w shoulders; knee length frock coats. Bowlers; derbies; fed hats. BOB selects a fine white shirt, white underwear and a hea suit. He crowns his head with a black bowler hat that is black silk. The STORE OWNER totals the prices on a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: STORE OWNER
dialogues.text: You come into some money, is that?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You might say that.

dialogues.speaker: STORE OWNER
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I ask how you got it, being’s you‘re so young?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Only thing necessary is a great aunt who loves her nephew to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: STORE OWNER
dialogues.text: Inheritance. I see.  32 BOB puts his finger on the twine intersection so the STOR make a knot.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You were probably thinking I got the cash like the James gang would. Am I right or wrong? The STORE OWNER winks.

dialogues.speaker: STORE OWNER
dialogues.text: Don’t think I don’t appreciate the business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB exits and mounts his horse. A moment later the STOREO out. He crosses the street to the livery and approaches S TIMBERLAKE. We can’t make out his words but he points in BOB has ridden in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB approaches on horseback. EXT. YARD, HARBISON FARM - DAY. DICK LIDDIL is at the yard swing with Bob’s niece, IDA (1 twisting the seat until the ropes are raveled. He release twirls, squealing, her auburn hair flying out. WOOD HITE stands on the kitchen porch, stern as John the

dialogues.speaker: WOOD
dialogues.text: You’re gonna make her sick! She’s gonna upchuck, you don’t watch out! DICK cuffs the girl's dress so that it blooms and reveals

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: You’re not supposed to peek, Dick!

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: But you‘re so pretty! I can’t help myself! BOB, approaching, calls:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Howdy! But they ignore him. WOOD, jealous, slams the screen door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB can be heard before he’s seen:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Howdy !  33 Neither CHARLEY nor MARTHA BOLTON (BOB & CHARLEY’S SISTER

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Howdy! BOB enters, making a b-line for the staircase and his bed

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’m finally home!

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I'm real glad, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I’m in that room too, Bob. Don’t mess up my things. INT. 2° FLOOR BEDROOM, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - DAY. BOB reaches under his bed and hooks out a shoe-box. He op and lays it on the bed. From his pocket he removes a ciga wraps it in the eye-holed white handkerchief. He tucks th bundle into the box alongside about lurid nickel books ab gang, civil war photographs, yellowed newspaper articles, James brothers’ mementoes. Then he squirms his boots off of his month old clothes. INT. HARBISON HOMESTEAD ~ DAY. BOB comes downstairs in his filthy union suit. He carries cake of soap and a tile brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two calves stare with worry as BOB takes a bath in the br tank. BOB bends over to rinse soap from his hair and then like a hound. Then he notices an amused DICK LIDDIL stand as a tailor.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: How long you been there?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Just now arrived. Did I miss much?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Not unless you've never seen a man wash his dirty carcass before.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: You've got a big Pecker for being such a little squirrel. BOB . Is that what you come over here to see? pack bends for the towel and some of the good nature slid ace.  34

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Your brother said Jesse kept you in Kansas City some extra days. What was the reason? Bob rubs his hair wild.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, I’m not at liberty to say exactly. I will confess we had an adventure or two, the like of which you'll never experience, but as for details and whatnot, that would be confidential. BOB straddles the tank and surrounds himself with the tow

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Let me ask you this: did Jesse mention that me and Cummins were in cahoots?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Oh dear. I’ve went on and said too much.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Who else is partners with you two?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: You'll just go and squawk about it to Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Ed Miller?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: He'll cut our throats if he finds out. You don’t know him like I do. You do Jesse dirt, you connive behind his back, he’ll come after you with a cleaver.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: He can be spiteful, can he?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Ho. You're darn tootin’.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Don‘t see why he’d give a dang since he and Frank‘ve called it quits and scattered the James gang hither and yon. DICK studies BOB but sees neither cunning nor deception.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Boy, you really are as slow as peach mold, you know that? Tucker Bassham’s already gone for ten years and whiskyhead Ryan's in jail; goon as one or the other feels the urge he can give the government all he knows about Jesse and then go out on the street scot- free. Jesse don’t want us giving ourselves up and he don’t want us getting caught and he don’t want us gathering loot except if he’s in charge. BOB rolls his eyes in exasperation, then clutches the tow and reaches down for his holster. DICK pins it with his b

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Let me carry your six-gun for you, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: All right. They take no more than two strides towards the house befo insisted the revolver under the towel with the barrel aga scrotum.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: You and me, we horse around and josh each other with lies and tomfoolery, but now and then we need to get down to brass tacks. Which is: you so much as mention my name to Jesse, I'll find out about it, you better believe that. And then I’1l look you up, I’11l knock on your door, and I will be as mad as a hornet, I will be hot.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You be careful with that iron.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: You know where I stand on these matters and that’s all there is to it. We can be friendly as pigs from now on.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Could be I'll never see Jesse again. DICK draws the screen door wide for Bob and then restrict shoulders as he pries his boots off with the bootjack.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Oh no. I’ve got a hunch about it. Jesse will come courtin’ Ed and Jim and me, and he'll find himself in the neighborhood and call on them two Ford brothers. Jesse don’t miss much. He has a sixth sense. INT. MARTHA’S BEDROOM, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - DAY  36 BOB dresses in his new clothes, selected according to Jes preferences. But while these clothes might suit Jesse Jam particularly suit ROBERT FORD. INT. 2° FLOOR BEDROOM, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - DAY. BOB enters to find CHARLEY and WOOD rooting through his m

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You two have some nerve! BOB elbows them aside and begins repacking the shoe-box. up a photograph.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: This ain’t Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You don’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Never wore no mustache; never was anywheres near a cannon. wooD I can’t even calculate what I’m lookin’ at.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Ever since he was a child, Bob‘s collected whatsoever he could find about the James brothers. Got himself a little museum in this room, BOB rams the nightstand’s door closed. He’s humiliated, a tears:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Next time you snoop around up here you better strap on a shootin’ iron.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: You can see how scared I am.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You too, Wood Hite. You cross me again and I’11 put a bullet through your head.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Now is that any way to talk? WOOD pokes BOB onto the bed.  37

dialogues.speaker: WOOD
dialogues.text: (sneers) You better recollect who my cousin is. You seem to’ve misremembered that Jesse loves me like the Good Book. You can play like you’re a dangerous person at the grocery store, but don‘t you misremember who you'll be accounting to if I so much as have my feelings hurt.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (OFF-SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Do I have to yell suwee?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Why don’t everyone make up and be pleasant for once? Why don’t we pass the evening like pleasant human beings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DICK enters with his coat and bags. MARTHA kisses him on whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Oh, Goodness! Maybe I’11 change my mind. But then WOOD is behind him, jealously bumping him toward

dialogues.speaker: WOOD
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DICK and WOOD take mount their horses and wave goodbye to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride sullenly. WOOD reads a penny newspaper four inc nose. DICK watches the geography sail by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DICK and WOOD approach the HITE family home. Two EX-SLAVE in a field. A BLACK WOMAN pins laundry on a clothesline. MRS SARAH HITE stands up from her weeding and excitedly w pert and pretty. wood . You keep your hands off this one. She’s my Daddy's wife. INT. DINING ROOM, HITE HOMESTEAD - NIGHT. Dinner in silence: SARAH sits next to her ancient and ema HUSBAND. The atmosphere is becoming strained, so DICK lea pot roast:  38

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: You cook this, ma’am? She shakes her head:

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I've got a nigger woman. MAJOR GEORGE HITE raises an ear trumpet and inclines it t wife:

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR GEORGE HITE
dialogues.text: How’s that?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Dick asked if I cooked this?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR GEORGE HITE
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: No. MAJOR GEORGE HITE picks up SARAH’S hand and displays it t assembled like a greeting card.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR GEORGE HITE
dialogues.text: You boys ever seen such dainty nubbins? Sarah‘s my plumb little Plumb. He grins at her red-faced resentment. DICK looks at his k wooD She knew what he was like when she married him. EXT. PORCH, HITE HOMESTEAD - NIGHT. MRS SARAH HITE sits in a rocking chair with her needlewor out and leans on the porch rail. Finally, he says:

dialogues.speaker: DI
dialogues.text: I guess we’re the night owls, you and me. She simpers but does not look up. I’m glad.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Oh? How come?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You have a real pleasant disposition; you're - interesting to look at; and, I don’t know, you sort of make me warm all over.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I’m what they call a worldling.  39

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Well, I knew there had to be a name for it.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: You and the Hite family don’t get along, if I‘m to trust Wood and his version of the situation.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: We hate each other like poison, if you want to know the truth. Most of the Hites wouldn't spit on me if I was on fire. DICK grins:

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: They say when a woman catches fire you're supposed to roll her around on the ground and cover her with your body. Sarah laughs and clamps her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You naughty tease! You tickle me to such an extent that my cheeks are burning up. WOOD appears at the screen door, scowling, in his night s wooD Isn’t it about bedtime?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I‘1l just kiss those dainty nubbins. And, as he does so, SARAH giggles. INT. HITE HOMESTEAD - NIGHT. DICK follows WOOD up to the second floor bedroom. INT. BEDROOM, HITE HOMESTEAD - LATER. DICK is tucked under the bedsheet. He whacks his pillow. stirs.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I drank too much coffee. He sits up to see WOOD glaring at him from the bunk oppos

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I need to visit the privy something terrible. INT. CORRIDOR, HITE HOMESTEAD - NIGHT. DICK sneaks down to the master bedroom and pushes the doo DICK‘S POV:  40 MAJOR GEORGE HITE is alone in the bed, puttering a snore. EXT. PORCH, HITE HOMESTEAD - NIGHT. DICK exits, careful not to let the screen door clap behin EXT. LAWN, HITE HOMESTEAD - NIGHT. He crosses the lawn to the outhouse in back: An interior can be seen through each severance and crack. DICK looks then slips inside. INT. OUTHOUSE, HITE HOMESTEAD - NIGHT. SARAH sits with her dress hiked up and collected like lau are downcast, but she seems less shocked than amused:

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: This is embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: You go ahead and do your duty; I don’t mind.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Well now, I’ve sort of got stage fright with a strange man in the commode with me.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: You look awful pretty.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Do I?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I’ve never seen such well-shaped limbs. She glances fleetingly at the bent pronouncement at his c

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Is Wood awake?

dialogues.speaker: DICK '
dialogues.text: Just me. . She considers her knees for a moment and then blows out t

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I bet you thought I was a lady. EXT. LAWN, HITE HOMESTEAD - NIGHT. DICK exits the outhouse and crosses toward the porch. He Colt revolver clutched in his right hand. A gunshot is heard - A noise like the snare of a saw cuts DICK’S ear - and a chunk of gray bark explodes from the b behind him. Dick ducks behind it.  41

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Wood? No response.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: You’re making this more grievous than you oughta, Wood. He cocks his Navy Colt with quavering hands.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Can’t we talk about it? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I'll shoot! So help me, I’m scared enough to be real undependable with this Colt. DICK bends out and WOOD fires a second time. DICK ducks in reaction but sees WOOD'S flash in the folia DICK raises his gun and fires once. He then snaps the ham detonated cartridges. Panic. He turns and sees the MAJOR GEORGE HITE and the SERVANTS behind the screen door. He runs clumsily toward them. WOOD shoots at his back twice - missing both times. EXT. PORCH, HITE HOMESTEAD - NIGHT. DICK trips on the stairs and wallops into a slide across MAJOR GEORGE HITE steps out and Hollers at his son:

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR GEORGE HITE
dialogues.text: Here now! Stop this! Wood! I won’t have any gunplay on my property! I’ve told you a thousand times. WOOD answers with a shot - nailing a dark hole in the win GEORGE HITE stamps and yells:

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR GEORGE HITE
dialogues.text: Wood! You listen to me! No more! WOOD steps out, looks down at his revolver, and clicks th around. woOoD That was my last bullet anyways. Something must be wrong with the sight on this thing. MAJOR GEORGE HITE looks down at the cowering DICK:  42

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR GEORGE HITE
dialogues.text: What‘s the reason for this ruckus? Huh? DICK sees SARAH slink over to her husband. He rises.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Me and Wood, we just had a misunderstanding, is all.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR GEORGE HITE
dialogues.text: You know what? You've worn out your welcome, young fellow.

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: EXT. ED MILLER’S CABIN - DUSK ED MILLER at the screen-door with a gun in his hand and f eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: You come by for a visit?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (0/S)
dialogues.text: You going to let me in or do I have to talk through the screen? INT. ED MILLER’S CABIN - CONTINUOUS JESSE enters. The room is a mess: Mold crusted dishes sta kitchen table; newspapers shucked like .corn against the a cat on the kitchen cutting board licking something from tipped over; the sink.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You aren’t much of a housekeeper, are you?

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: You didn’t just happen by.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Why not? ! JESSE looks at the gun and MILLER puts it on the kitchen JESSE sits himself down on the ringed rug. He nods toward couch:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Go ahead and take a load off your feet. MILLER does as instructed. His clothes are wrinkled as cr his fingernails are outlined with filth, a corner of his stained with tobacco juice.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You ought to get yourself a wife.  43

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: I was going to ask Martha - Charley's sister? I was going to ask her if she could imagine it, but I guess Wood has plans of his own, and there's always Dick Liddil getting in the way. I've give it some thought. MILLER can't seem to put his eyes on JESSE. His right foo the floor.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Your crops in?

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: Don’t got much. A garden patch and pasture. I was sick at planting time.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: How you feeling now? A fleeting glance at JESSE:

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You‘re acting queer.

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: You and me, we haven't been just real good friends lately. It’s not your fault, you understand. You hear talk though.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Talk?

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: People tell you things.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Give me an example.

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: Jim Cummins come by. Oh and Jim says - you know those boys got caught for the Blue Cut deal? - Jim says he got word - don’t ask me where - that you’re planning to kill them.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Why would I do that? MILLER shoots a glance at JESSE’S gun hand and then reest gaze on the yard.

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: It’s just talk probably.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: To shut ‘em up?  44

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: Just talk.

dialogues.speaker: . JESSE
dialogues.text: Cummins say anything else?

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: Nope. That was it basically.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It don‘t explain why you're scared. MILLER looks at him with watery eyes and spit on his mout glinting off the oils on his skin.

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: I’m in the same position, you see? I was petrified when I saw you ride up!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I just happened by, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: Suppose you heard gossip though. Suppose you heard Jim Cummins come by here. You might've thought we were planning to capture you or Frank and get that reward. Isn't true, but you might've suspected it. JESSE gets up and jiggles a pants leg over his boot.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Haven't heard a lick of gossip lately. JESSE looks out at the road and at the sky which is pink The road he looks down seems never-ending.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I’m glad I happened by.

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER, (OFF-SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I want to put your mind at rest.

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER, (OFF-SCREEN)
dialogues.text: I’ve got six hundred dollars stashed away; I don‘t need any governor’s reward.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It’s the principle of the thing too. MILLER pulls himself to his feet and sweeps his hand over shoo away flies.  45

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: How about if we go for a ride? I could buy you something to eat in town and then be on my way. EXT. ED MILLER’S CABIN - NIGHT MILLER saddles his mare as JESSE sits on a gelding with t falling all around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head westerly, the horses easing into a graceful lop into a walk.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You ever count the stars? MILLER looks overhead at the pinpricks of light.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I can’t ever get the same number; they keep changing on me.

dialogues.speaker: ED MILLER
dialogues.text: I don’t even know what a star is exactly.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Your body knows; it’s your mind that forgot. MILLER can’t get himself to say anything. JESSE pretends his cinch, slows his horse.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You go on ahead, partner. I'll catch up. MILLER slumps in his saddle, tears forming in his eyes. J his gun from the leather holster and then jogs his horse stops on the road but can’t persuade himself to drop a ha pistol or even to turn around.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: {rounding him) You ought to get better at lying. JESSE trips the hammer and a cartridge ball pounds into M snaps his head to the side and propels his body off the m wallops onto the road. JESSE gets off his horse and tugs legs, towing the body towards a cluster of Elm trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ED MILLER'S MARE browsing riderless in a paddock:  46

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: The sitting room conversations were all about Blue Cut that week: the Kansas City newspapers carried front-page articles about the arrests of Jobn Bugler, John Land, and Creed Chapman in shacks near Glendale. Creed Chapman would lose forty-two pounds while imprisoned and John Land was rumored to be so apprehensive about reprisal by Jesse James that he refused to even mention the man’s name. INT. DICK’S BEDROOM, KANSAS CITY - NIGHT. DICK doesn’t know what wakes him. He looks from his sleep (MATTIE) to the light spilling through the bedroom doorwa transfixed by it. A sound begins to build. Hairs stand up of bis neck. He retrieves his Navy Colt from under his pi slides quietly out of bed. INT. DICK'S KITCHEN, KANSAS CITY - NIGHT. DICK enters and almost screams: JESSE JAMES sits like an apparition at his kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You want to go for a ride? EXT. ROAD, OUTSIDE KANSAS CITY - DAWN. They head their horses through the cold. DICK is suspicio unnerved.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Are we going to your place? JESSE puts his finger inside his cheek and flicks out the tobacco chew.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You seen Ed Miller lately?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Nobody has.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Must’ve gone off to California. DICK looks at him with perplexity.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I got word about you and Wood. You ought to patch things up.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I‘d still like to know where we’re going.  47

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: If you were going to see Jim Cummins, wouldn’t you follow this road?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, Dick; use your head. EXT. BILL FORD’S FARM (ESTABLISHING) - DAY JESSE and DICK approach the farmhouse. INT. BILL FORD’S FARMHOUSE - DAY A 12-year-old boy (ALBERT FORD) stands at the sitting roo watches the two men climb down from their saddles. EXT. PORCH, BILL FORD'S FARMHOUSE ~ DAY. The boy creaks open the door and comes outside:

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Hello. But he’s ignored as JESSE reconnoiters the yard and then ascends the steps. DICK can see past the nervous ALBERT t where TWO WOMEN stir clothes in a laundry boiler. JESSE p other rooms.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Are you friends of my Pa’s?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: We're friends of Jim Cummins.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Oh. ALBERT gains thirty years - becomes sullen. ‘ALBERT Well, it so happens he’s been gone since August and never said where he gone to.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I’m Matt Collins. DICK shakes the boy’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Very happy to meet you. JESSE clenches the boy’s hand and introduces himself.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Dick Turpin.  48

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Pleased to make your acquaintance. JESSE smiles around the cigar but stalls the shake and cr hand until the boy winces. ALBERT is about to cry out whe his hand over the boy’s mouth and yanks him into the yard shuts the mahogany door. EXT. YARD, BILL FORD‘S FARM - DAY JESSE manhandles the boy toward a red barn stopping to sl a cottonwood tree so that he loses his wind. DICK shamble looking apprehensive and ashamed, checking the road. INT. BARN, BILL FORD’S FARM - DAY JESSE throws the boy to the ground and steps a boot onto

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Come on, Jesse! He’s just a kid. JESSE glowers at DICK for letting his name slip, then ret attention to the choking boy.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: He knows where his uncle Jim is and that’s gonna make him old pretty soon. ALBERT brawls and kicks at JESSE.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Maybe he doesn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: He knows. JESSE falls to his knees on the boy’s biceps. ALBERT crie clamps the boy’s mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You need to ask and ask sometimes. Sometimes a child won't remember much at first and then it‘1l all come back. Just tell me about your Uncle Jim is. Where’d he sneak off to; where's he hidin’ out? He twists the boy’s ear like a clock wind-up and ALBERT’S wildly, his boots thud the earth. JESSE leans over to exa injury.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: My gosh, I believe it’s about to tear, sweetie. Just a little more to get her started, then I can rip your ear off like a page from a book.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Let the kid go.  49

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: He’s lying.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Jesus; he can’t even talk!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Where's Jim? (beat) Where’s Jim? Where's Jim? Where's Jim?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: (slapping JESSE'S hat off his head) Quit it! JESSE sits back and rubs his hands on his thighs. ALBERT can’t make words. He wipes his nose and eyes and shudders he gasps for air. When at last he speaks his voice is sca child's:

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: You bastard! I don’t know where he is and you won't believe me and you never even gave me a chance. You kept my mouth shut! I never know where Jim is or when he comes so leave me alone, get off me, you son of a bitch! (grunts and bucks under JESSE and shouts: } Get off! JESSE rises and ALBERT rolls over crying. DICK walks out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DICK walks around the barn to the road, his face splotche fury. He climbs onto his mount. When JESSE comes forward, DICK looks away; squints down t order to talk.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I‘m worn out Jesse. I cant- My mind’s all tangled anyway. Little deals like that just make me feel dirty. DICK turns to gauge JESSE’S reaction to this and is aston him caved forward into his bay horse, his face flattened in a grimace of affliction, noiselessly crying.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: You all right, Jesse? JESSE nuzzles into the horse’s hide and mutters words we out. ALBERT limps toward the Ford house, cupping his left ear nose with his sleeve.  30

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Maybe you better ride on to wherever it is you're living now, and maybe I'll sell this animal and skeedaddle on over to Mrs. Bolton's and, you know, apologize to the Fords; put everything in it’s best light and so on. JESSE scrubs at his eyes. He fumbles his left boot at the at last it finds purchase and he swings up.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I must be going crazy. And he rides off without another word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOOD HITE approaches through the arctic wind. His moustac with ice. Snow has made boards of his trousers and sleeve He sees ELIAS FORD (BOB & CHARLEY’S ELDER BROTHER) in the throwing up his arm in greeting and pointing him toward t INT. BARN, HARBISON FARM ~ MORNING. WOOD walks his horse inside a stall and throws a moth eat over it. EXT. YARD, HARBISON FARM - MORNING. WOOD walks to the kitchen with WILBUR, who's teetering wi (WILBUR is another FORD BROTHER, in between BOB and CHARL wooD How come it’s always you who does the chores?

dialogues.speaker: WILBUR
dialogues.text: Charley and Bob pay extree to Martha so’s they don’t have to. wooD Still don’t seem fair.

dialogues.speaker: WILBUR
dialogues.text: Well. WILBUR opens the storm door for the man and bangs the mil

dialogues.speaker: WILBUR
dialogues.text: I‘d take a rag to my nose if I were you; it’s unsightly. INT. KITCHEN, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - MORNING.  31 MARTHA kneads bread dough on a floured board. IDA stirs a yawning. WILBUR straddles a chair and MARTHA turns to see his right ear over the coal lamp's glass chimey.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Look what the cat dragged in. He rotates his ear to thaw the left ear.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: You come from Kentucky? WOOD squints at her:

dialogues.speaker: WOOD
dialogues.text: You mean the news never got this far?

dialogues.speaker: WILBUR
dialogues.text: Wood and Dick had a shooting scrape a month or two ago. INT. 2" FLOOR BEDROOM, HARBISON HOMESTEAD — MORNING. BOB is awake upstairs. The North window is raised and the cold spirits leave him with each exhalation. The sounds o being prepared below:

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (OFF-SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Cover the kettle, Ida. Then he hears his sister say:

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (OFF-SCREEN)
dialogues.text: What on earth did you and Dick get into a fracas about? And he bolts out of bed. He scoots his hand under DICK’S shakes him:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Dick! LIDDIL automatically reaches for the colt revolver but fi trapped. He looks at BOB’S worried face.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Wood Hite’s downstairs. INT. KITCHEN, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - MORNING.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
