dialogues.text: I-da! Don’t stick your thumb in the cream when you skim it! Goodness sakes!

dialogues.speaker: WILBUR
dialogues.text: Dick told me a complete other version of that affray.  52 woOD You mean he’s here?

dialogues.speaker: WILBUR
dialogues.text: Came in late last night. WOOD'S chair screeches on the floor as he stands up.

dialogues.speaker: WILBUR
dialogues.text: Simmer down. INT. 2" FLOOR BEDROOM, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - MORNING. DICK cocks his Navy Colt and points it at the closed door a loaded revolver from CHARLEY’S holster.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (OFF-SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Don’t you boys get into a fracas up there. I’ve almost got breakfast cooked. They listen as WOOD makes a racket on the stairs. WOOD slams the bedroom door with his boot so that it bash and CHARLEY jolts up. DICK fires a shot, missing WOOD and smashing a hole in th WOOD fires at DICK strewing pillow feathers, and fires a DICK rolls off the mattress. A terrified BOB cowers next to his bed and clicks back th his revolver. WOOD fires a shot through DICK’S thigh; swatting the floo bed sheets with blood. DICK triggers a shot that snags WOOD’S right arm. CHARLEY gets out of bed and dives for the windowsill, squ the sash. WOOD shoots at CHARLEY but misses. ext.’ ROOF, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - MORNING CHARLEY slips on the eave and slides off the roof and whu snowbank twelve feet below. INT. 2” FLOOR BEDROOM, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - MORNING. DICK, in agony, raises his Navy Colt again but the hammer an empty chamber. WOOD then switches his pistol to his left hand, steps for takes slow and careful aim at DICK. It is then that BOB FORD shoots ROBERT WOODSON HITE: The just next to his eyebrow and makes a small button of red shuts WOOD'S motor off. wooD collapses to his knees, his  33 jelly and reason vanishes, and then he falls to the left concussion that jostles the room. DICK looks at BOB with consternation. BOB walks around to WOOD with sickness in his stomach, an his throat.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Is he dead? BOB is deafened by the gunfire:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Is he dead? WOOD'S chest swells and relaxes. Blood pools wide as a bi his skull.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: He’s still sucking air, but I think he’s a goner. INT. 2" FLOOR CORRIDOOR, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - MORNING. BOB steps shakily out into the corridor and looks down at ELIAS at the bottom of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (holding it together) Maybe you oughta come up and wish him well on his journey. Blood creeps away from WOOD and drools into board cracks. it as the stairs creak.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (little boy lost) He’s losing all his stuffing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTHA bumps past BOB, removes her apron, and carefully w the exit wound. ELIAS squats next to her.

dialogues.speaker: ELIAS
dialogues.text: You were a good fellow, Wood. You talked kindly and you took care of your horse and you always pulled your own weight.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I hope the pain isn’t frightful, Wood. I'd fetch something for you to drink but I’m afraid it’d just make you choke. (beat)  54 Little Ida‘’s going to miss you. So isthe rest of the family. DICK collars his thigh with his hands.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Hitch my leg up onto the bed so that it won’t dispense so easy. He grits his teeth when ELIAS grips his ankle and sags ba when ELIAS lifts it onto the mattress. BOB steps into the room and stands over WOOD.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Just in case you never noticed. It was me who shot you. I don't harbor any ill feelings toward you, I was just scared and looking out for my own well-being. A finger ticks on WOOD’S left hand and BOB jumps back an recovering his composure.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You‘ve done a gallant job of dying so far and have nothing whatsoever to be ashamed about. INT. KITCHEN, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - AFTERNOON. CHARLIE sits with his foot propped up on a chair, his spr round as a melon.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: One thing’s settled: can’t take him into Richmond.

dialogues.speaker: WILBUR
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: One: the sheriff will put Bob in jail. And two: Jesse will find out his cousin Wood's been shot in our house and that'll be the end for each and every one of us. IDA comes inside from the root cellar with vegetable jars her weeping mother.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Does Uncle Bob like okra, Momma?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Can’t you see him standing there? Why don’t you find out for yourself? BOB loiters with the shell of the bullet, sniffing the bu in it.  55

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: She's afraid of me, Martha. (Beat) You all are. INT. 2" FLOOR BEDROOM, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - DUSK. WOOD'S corpse, now naked, is laid out on BOB’S twin bed. move as he reads a yellow book. BOB enters. DICK doesn’t eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: He ain't disappeared if that’s what you were hoping.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What chapter are you on?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: She’s seen some young swell and got herself all agitated.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: How's your leg?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Full of torment, Bob. Thanks for asking. BOB sets his tin plate down and lowers himself onto DICK’ examines the excavation in WOOD'S skull.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I ought to feel sorry but I don’t. I’m just glad it’s Wood who's dead and not me. DICK closes the book on his index finger. He looks at BOB

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: You and me, we'll have to sit down and talk a few things over. Circumstances have changed. (nods to WOOD) He’1l cut our throats, if he finds out. You don’t know Jesse like I do. He‘ll kill us in our sleep. BOB sighs; the gravity of his situation sinking in on him is standing in the doorway with a moth eaten blanket.

dialogues.speaker: ELIAS
dialogues.text: Ready? INT. HARBISON HOMESTEAD - DUSK. ELIAS and BOB tow the body down the stairs. INT. KITCHEN, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - DUSK. CHARLEY and WILBUR solemly rise from their chairs as WOOD out. IDA covers her face with her palms and MARTHA turns  56 EXT. HARBISON FARM - DUSK. Snow falls around BOB and ELIAS as they struggle with the load. EXT. RAVINE, HARBISON FARM - DUSK. WOOD'S naked body is rolled into a snow filled ravine. Th begin kick clods of earth down onto the body.

dialogues.speaker: ELIAS, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Blessed are the poor in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. Blessed are they that mourn: for they shall be comforted. EXT, SLOPE ABOVE RAVINE, HARBISON FARM — LATER. ELIAS stands with hat at his chest, petitioning BOB with

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Meek.

dialogues.speaker: ELIAS
dialogues.text: Blessed are the meek.. ELIAS pauses and beseeches his brother again.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: For they shall inherit the earth.

dialogues.speaker: INT, HARBISON HOMESTEAD
dialogues.text: BOB sits, spooked, in the living room. The clock clunks. out. BOB turns to lock eyes with an apparition at the windowgl receding back into the darkness. And then suddenly JESSE is filling up the kitchen, as lar as a beer wagon: Rowdily swatting shoulders and biceps, r other FORD BROTHER'S handshakes. BOB scuttles up the stairs. INT. 2 FLOOR BEDROOM, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - DUSK. DICK is already hopping one-leggedly toward the closet.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Why‘d he come by, Dick? Does he know about Wood, do you think?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I can’t figure it, Bob. I only know that he doesn’t miss very much.  57

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What should I say about you if he asks?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Just tell him I’m in K.C. with Mattie. Dick swaddles himself in yanked-down petticoats and crino closes the closet door. INT. KITCHEN, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - SOON AFTER. BOB shies into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Why, it’s the kid!

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: How's everything? JESSE ignores question and takes off his hat and coat. No JESSE moves - it’s as if his acts are miracles of inventi behold.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I never take off my gunbelt.

dialogues.speaker: WILBUR
dialogues.text: Good thinking. JESSE walks back to his coffee and CHARLEY hitches aside.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Hurt your leg?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I slipped off the roof and smacked down into a snowbank like a ton of stupidness. One second I’m screaming, ‘Whoa, Nelly!’ and the next second, poof! I’m neck deep in snow.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: The roof? Whatever possessed you to climb the roof in December? : CHARLEY loses his smile and sees the criticism in BOB’S e

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: (stammering) There was a kite- what am I saying? There was a cat. A cat was on the roof and I went after him. A tom cat. Yowling and whatall; and I slipped. CHARLIE rubs his eye and coughs into his fist.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I thought maybe your clubfoot was gaining on ya.  58 WILBUR and CHARLEY guffaw as if this is funny. MARTHA car ham hocks to the table.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Dick was here for a little bit and then he went on to Kansas City to be with his wife. JESSE gives BOB a look and then pretends he hasn’‘t heard tickle IDA’S side and stomach, saying ‘Kootchy Kootch’ un is sore with giggles, and the fun is over.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Oh, quit it, you two. CHARLEY casts about anxiously for something to say.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Here’s a cute story, Jess. Bobby was - what -— eleven or twelve? And you were by far his most admired personage. He couldn’t get enough. He practically ate those newspaper stories up. It was Jesse this, Jesse that, “* from sunrise to sunset.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Fascinating.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: No; there’s more. This is cute. We're at Supper and Bob asks, ‘You know what size boot Jesse wears?’

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Jesse doesn’t care about this, Charley.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Shush now, Bob. Let me tell it. Bob says, he says ‘You know what size boot Jesse wears? Six and a half,’ He says, ‘Ain’t that a little boot for a man five feet eight inches tall?’ Well, I decide to josh hima little, you know, so I said, ‘He doesn’t have toes, ' is why.’ .

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Really stupid.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Then my momma pipes up and says, ‘He what?’ and I’m not letting on. I say, ‘He was dangling his feet off a culvert and a catfish nibbled his toes off.‘ Well, Bob taxed himself trying to picture it until Momma let on that I was playing him the fool. And Bob says ~ I want to get this right. What was it exactly you said, Bob?  59

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (reluctant) I said, ‘If they’d been catfish he'd a drilled them with his forty-four.’ CHARLEY laughs and claps his hands.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Yep, that’s the exact words, exactly! Jesse looks at BOB without comment.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It'd be a good joke if it was funny.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: You've got to picture it though. Bob saying you would‘ve shot them catfish, then smiling in every direction, real satisfied with himself. Oh! And you know what he said next? He said, ‘You need your toes.’

dialogues.speaker: WILBUR
dialogues.text: How'd I miss this? Where was I?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: You need your toes.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: ‘Course you do.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Isn’t that a cute story? JESSE suppresses his opinion. He regards BOB in a way tha sight is disappointing. He skewers a cigar with the tine

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Give me some other conversations, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (reluctant) ' You know how children are. :

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It‘d be cheery to hear what you fancied about me. It might make me laugh and forget my cares and woes.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I can‘t recall much of any consequence.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I got one. This one’s about as crackerjack as the one about your toes.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Which?  60

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: About how much you and Jesse have in common.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you tell it, Bob; if you remember.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, if you'll pardon my saying so, it is interesting, the many ways you and I overlap and whatnot. You begin with our Daddies. Your daddy was a pastor of the New Hope Baptist Church; my daddy was pastor of a church at Excelsior Springs. You're the youngest of the three James boys; I’m the youngest of the five Ford boys. You had twins as sons, I have twins as sisters. Between Charley and me, is another brother, Wilbur here (with six letters in his name); between Frank and you was a brother, Robert, also with six letters. Robert, of course, is my Christian name. You have blue eyes; I have blue eyes. You're five feet eight inches tall. I’m five feet eight inches tall. Oh.me, I must’ve had a list as long as your nightshirt when I was twelve, but I’ve lost some curiosities over the years. JESSE is as still as a photograph. Smoke spirals from his line and then squiggles above him like sloppy handwriting are active, cagey, calculating. He comes carefully to lif ashes into his coffee cup.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Did I ever mention that scalawag George Shepherd to y’all? He reaches over and grips BOB’S forearm in apology while JESSE (CONT’D) George was one of Quantrill’s lieutenants and he gave me a story like Bob’s, is why I thought of him, giving me everything we had in common and so on, just so he could join the gang. How could I know he had a grudge against me and was lying to get on my good side? I said ‘Come aboard, George. Glad to have ya,’ George thought he was pretty smart. ‘Cept he wasn’t. He rode into camp one morning and about twenty guns opened up on him. But he only had one eye - and you need two eyes to get Jesse. BOB and WILBUR laugh for a suitable period of time, and J until tears come out of his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You oughtn’t think of me like you do George Shepherd.  61

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You just brought him to mind.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It’s not very flattering. MARTHA waitresses around them collecting cups and saucers

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Good eating, Martha.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Glad you liked it.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: How come George had a grudge against you?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You said George Shepherd had a grudge against you and I’ve just been wondering what it was?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh. George asked me to protect this nephew of his during the war and it so happens the kid had five thousand dollars on him. The kid winds up killed, and all the money swiped from him, and when George was in prison someone whispers to him it was Jesse James slit the boy's throat.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Just mean gossip, was it?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Bob’s the expert; put it to him. BOB rises from the table like a stamping boy in a snit.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I’ve make him cranky. WILBUR snickers.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I've been through this before, is all. once people get around to making fun of me, they just don’t ever let up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Someone’s speaking awful fresh over there! BOB is forced to walk Past JESSE to get to the main room. leg across BOB’S Path, clouting the floorboards with his glances down at his bogus grin - the suggestion of malice antics.  62

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to skip off to your room and pout without knowing why I dropped by for this visit.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I suppose you're going to tell us how sorry you are that you had to slap my cousin Albert around. Such great heat seems to come then from JESSE'S eyes that away as if from sunlight, but in a second the man cools a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I come to ask one of you two Fords to ride with me on a journey or two. I guess we've agreed it ought to be Charley; you've been acting sort of testy. BOB stands pale and silent. Then he steps around JESSE’S calmly climbs the stairs to the upper room. INT. 2 FLOOR BEDROOM, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - NIGHT. BOB enters and carefully shuts the door. DICK shoves open door with his toe and looks out at ROB.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I'd say that was really stupid. EXT. SAMUEL'S FARM, KEARNEY (ESTABLISHING) - NIGHT. JESSE and CHARLEY approach on horseback. EXT. PORCH, SAMUEL’S FARMHOUSE, KEARNEY - NIGHT. ZERELDA SAMUELS (Jesse’s mother) is in the doorway waitin

dialogues.speaker: ZERELDA
dialogues.text: You're Charley Ford.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am you’ve seen me once or twice with Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: ZERELDA
dialogues.text: I got a letter from George Hite. Hasn’t seen hide nor hair of him. JESSE squints at CHARLEY.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: And you say you haven’t seen Wood?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Can’t imagine where he could be. INT. KITCHEN, SAMUEL’S FARMHOUSE, KEARNEY - NIGHT.  63 CHARLEY is woken by JESSE:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You finished with your sleeping? CHARLEY sits up from his bedroll:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I could use one or two more hours if it’s no trouble. I can’t operate on less than five. I run into walls and fence Posts.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I’ve been holding a discussion with myself over if I ought to tell you this or no. My good side won out and, well, I’d like to make a clean breast of things.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: My mind is cobwebby yet, is the only drawback. JESSE crosses close.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Can you hear me when I whisper this low? Just barely.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You knew I went to Kentucky?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I come back through Saline County and thought to myself, ‘why not Stop by and see Ed Miller?’ So I do and things aren’t to my satisfaction at all. Ed’s got himself worked up over something and I can tell he’s lying like a rug and I say to myself, ‘Enough’s enough!’ and I say to Ed, ‘Come on, Ed; let’s go for a ride.’ Do you understand what I’m saying?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Going for a ride is like giving him what-for.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Exactly. Ed and Jesse, they argued on the road and when push came to shove, Jesse shot and killed him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Jesse did.  64

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You’ve got it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: You. JESSE pats CHARLEY’S knee.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So you see? Your cousin got off easy. I was only playing with Albert.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I‘ve made him squeal once or twice myself. I’m just not as thorough as you are.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You want to swap a tale with me now?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: (sudden fright) I don’t get your meaning.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: If you’ve got something to confess in exchange, it seems to me it’d only be right for you to spit it out now. (beat) About Wood Hite, for example.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I’ve been saying over and over again I can’t figure out where he’s gone. I’m not going to change my story just to have something to spit.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Why was your brother so agitated?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Which?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Bob.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: It’s just his way. He’s antsy. JESSE retreats. Sits in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You can go back to sleep now.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: You got me agitated now: you see?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Just ain’t no peace with Jesse around. You ought to pity my poor wife.  65

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Ed Miller was a good friend of mine. He introduced me to you at that one poker game. I’m a little angry with you, if you want the God’s honest truth. JESSE crosses his ankles and shuts his eyes. He pushes hi into his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You ought to pity me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB walks through a street of mud and slush and manure. H two surreys and enters the Times Building. INT. HENRY CRAIG'S OFFICE, TIMES BUILDING - DAY. BOB stands in a room that’s full of bookcases housing Kan Missouri statutes. The door creaks and he turns to see a his late forties:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: My assistant mentioned something about you and the James gang.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yes sir. I want to bring them to justice.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: The James gang. BOB doesn’t react to his skepticism. Craig takes a seat b and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: How do you know the James brothers?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Did I say that I did?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: Do you spy on them?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You’1l excuse me for saying so, but isn’t what matters the fact that I can round these culprits up?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: I get told that once a week, and they’re still uncaught. You can see how I’d be skeptical. BOB lowers into a mahogany chair and admires the sculptur  66

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Just lately?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: Just lately what?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Anybody come to you just lately saying he could bring in one or two of the James gang?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: You‘ve got to give me something. I don’t even know your name.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It's Bob.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: Just Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now, yes; for the time being.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: Do you know where Jesse’s living?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: He was in Kansas City.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: (incredulous) You‘re pulling my leg.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Over on Woodland Avenue; and then Troost. He’s moved again though. CRAIG inscribes something in the journal and BOB walks ov the entry.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Does the name Bob Ford mean anything to you? CRAIG dips his quill pen in the ink bottle:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: Is that your actual name or your alias?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Actual. BOB watches his name recorded in CRAIG’S elegant calligra

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Pretty soon all America will know who Bob Ford is. EXT. WOODS SURROUNDING HARBISON HOMESTEAD - DAWN.  67 An ARMED POSSE crunch through the snow on foot, approachi Harbison farm. INT. 2” FLOOR BEDROOM, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - DAWN. Through the window, BOB sees 12 ARMED MEN coming out of t rounded over as hedgehogs. He swats at the sleeping DICK

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Dick! Dick inclines on his elbow and slants over just enough to wading through a knee-deep snowdrift. He bolts from the b clothes.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I_saw a tin star on someone's pocket; that’s all the information I need.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: God damn that Mattie anyhow. A big voice is heard coming from the yard:

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF TIMBERLAKE, (OFF-SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Jesse!

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: How do I find the attic? SHERIFF TIMBERLAKE (OFF-SCREEN CONT’D) We know you’re in there! Come outside with your hands up! EXT. HARBISON HOMESTEAD - DAWN. SHERIFF TIMBERLAKE has his mouth bracketed with his mitte surrounded by CRAIG and the DEPUTIES.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF TIMBERLAKE
dialogues.text: You boys are cornered! If you know what's good for you, you’1l come out peaceably and no one will get shot up! The kitchen door is pushed open and the MEN all crouch do out:

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (OFF-SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Don’t shoot!

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF TIMBERLAKE
dialogues.text: Come on out and show yourself! BOB steps out with a smirk.  68

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: If this isn’t a surprise!

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF TIMBERLAKE
dialogues.text: That’s how we intended it. INT. 2” FLOOR BEDROOM, HARBISON HOMESTEAD - SOON AFTER. The POSSE are gathered in the room. BOB and MARTHA watch whams the ceiling cover and points his revolver into the

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF TIMBERLAKE
dialogues.text: You there! Give yourself up! DICK climbs down. He is handcuffed.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: Andrew James Liddil, this is a warrant for your arrest for the murder of William Westfall and participation in the Winston train robbery on the 15™ of July, 1881.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB pilots a sleigh pulled by two horses, He approaches t Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB strolls the purple carpet of the lobby. It’s a world far unseen in the film. A world which BOB seems out of pl which he craves entry. He tugs off a mitten with his teet a sign announcing ‘The Craig Rifles Ball.’ INT. HENRY CRAIG’S SUITE, ST. JAMES HOTEL - DAY HENRY CRAIG is in a wood and tin bathtub that’s a@s narro He hears a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: . Come in. BOB sidles inside like a cat.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: Didn’t expect you to make it. BOB seats himself in a chair and slides his bowler hat be

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I couldn’t pass up meeting the Governor. Me and him’ve got some important matters to take up. CRAIG gives him an intolerant glance and then nods toward bottle:  69

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: How about some roockus juice?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Doesn't take more than a sip to make me want to bite off my own nose. CRAIG sloshes messily out of the tub and refills his glas

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: Well, this is my day! Here’s to the Craig Rifles and to the great man who leads them so magnificently.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Can I climb into that bathwater? I think I caught a chill on my way here.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: Go ahead. BOB strips and sinks into the tub with a groan.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: There’s something real seldom about you, Bob. INT. DINING ROOM, HENRY CRAIG’S SUITE, ST. JAMES HOTEL - BOB comes out just as two WAITERS trolly in a meal cart. to see DICK LIDDIL sitting at the dining table with HENRY Kansas City POLICEMEN. DICK laughs at BOB’S discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Well, well, well. Aren’t you just full of surprises.

dialogues.speaker: . BOB
dialogues.text: They're going to love a pretty boy like you in the penitentiary. You won’t never be lonely again.

dialogues.speaker: ' DICK
dialogues.text: Oh, they don’t give a damn about me. It’s Frank and Jesse they want. BOB sits down to carrots and rare steak. BOB cuts into hi considers the other men’s plates:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Is your cow still moving?

dialogues.speaker: DICK -
dialogues.text: Just singed it a little did they?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’ve seen critters worse off than this get well.  70

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: You're not going to be complaining all evening, are you?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Me? I’m happy, Henry! It’s the Craig Rifles Ball! It’s your night.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: Don‘t give the Governor your smart aleck talk.

dialogues.speaker: INT, GRAND BALLROOM, ST. JAMES HOTEL
dialogues.text: GOVENOR CRITTENDEN speaks to a large crowd of GENTLEMEN i LADIES in satin gowns

dialogues.speaker: CRITTENDEN
dialogues.text: I deem it a great privilege on this glorious occasion to recognize publicly the intelligent and efficient assistance that Captain Henry Craig has thus far provided the State of Missouri and myself in our joint quest to extirpate the James band from Jackson County. The task Henry Craig has assumed requires fearless courage, extraordinary vigilance, and an unerring selection of instrumentalities. BOB lingers against a pillar on the fringes.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (mutters to himself) You’re not so great. A WOMAN nearby glares at the comment.

dialogues.speaker: CRITTENDEN
dialogues.text: My wife has just signaled that I should leave well enough alone, so I‘1l leave you all with the wish for an enjoyable evening and with the hope that I may have the pleasure of meeting each of you before this celebration is ended. -

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: INT. CORRIDOR, ST. JAMES HOTEL — SOON AFTER The POLICEMEN shove BOB against a mahogany pillar. CRAIG

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: You're more trouble than you’re worth.  71

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: “ I was just going to say hello. we HENRY CRAIG That isn’t why you’re here. Get upstairs now and see if you can’t keep your identity secret. INT. HENRY CRAIG’S SUITE, ST. JAMES HOTEL - SOON AFTER BOB enters, looking disheveled. DICK, guarded by TWO KANS POLICEMEN, looks over the top of his paper and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: How was the party? INT. CRITTENDEN’S SUITE, ST. JAMES HOTEL - NIGHT CRITTENDEN receives them in a red silk robe and directs t wingback chairs:

dialogues.speaker: CRITTENDEN
dialogues.text: My wife’s asleep in the next room, so let’s speak as quietly as we can. CRITTENDEN settles himself into a settee and his eyes gli regards the two strangers:

dialogues.speaker: CRITTENDEN
dialogues.text: You're Dick little.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: — Liddil.

dialogues.speaker: CRITTENDEN
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I spell it with two @’s.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: He’s given us a confession but so far the newspapers haven’t caught onto it. You’ve guaranteed him a conditional pardon and amnesty for his robberies.

dialogues.speaker: CRITTENDEN
dialogues.text: You’re Robert Ford? BOB grins, but can’t think of anything to say.

dialogues.speaker: CRITTENDEN
dialogues.text: How old are you, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Twenty.  72

dialogues.speaker: CRITTENDEN
dialogues.text: Did you surrender to Sheriff Timberlake as well?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CRAIG
dialogues.text: It was his brother Charley who was in the James Gang. We couldn’t find anything on Bob. He's acting in the capacity of a private detective.

dialogues.speaker: CRITTENDEN
dialogues.text: I see. CRITTENDEN pours tea.

dialogues.speaker: CRITTENDEN
dialogues.text: Jesse James sent me a telegram last month, saying he was going to kill me if he had to wreck a train to do it. He said that once I was in his hands he was going to cut my heart out and eat in strips like it was bacon. (beat) I‘m going to wreck his train first. BOB emits a scoffing laugh. CRITTENDEN glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Your Excellency. I was thinking of something else.

dialogues.speaker: CRITTENDEN
dialogues.text: Jesse James is nothing more than a public outlaw who’s made his reputation by stealing whatever he could and by killing whoever got in his way. You‘ll hear some fools say he’s getting back at Republicans and Union men for wrongs his family suffered during the war, but his victims have scarcely ever been selected with reference to their political views. The GOVERNOR'S WIFE moans in the other room. CRITTENDEN t voice. .

dialogues.speaker: CRITTENDEN
dialogues.text: I'm saying his sins will soon find him out. I'm saying his cup of iniquity is full. I’m saying Jesse James is a desperate case and May require a desperate remedy. DICK looks to BOB to respond - but sees that the boy is o the situation, so he responds for him:

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: You've got the right man for the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 FOUL WEATHER.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (0/S)
dialogues.text: You ever consider suicide? CHARLEY and JESSE appear through the grey air:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Can’t say that I have. There was always something else I wanted to do. Or my predicaments changed or I saw my hardships from a different slant; you know all what can happen. It never seemed respectable. JESSE trots his mount forward:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I’1l tell you one thing that’s certain; you won’t fight dying once you've peeked over to the other side; you’ll no more want to go back to your body than you’d want to spoon up your own puke. JESSE vanishes again; leaving CHARLEY’S motor to work in

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: (calling after him) Since we’re looking to rob banks, I was wondering if I could go so far as to recommend we add another feller to the gang and sort of see if we couldn’t come out of our next job alive. JESSE, in his cloud, seems transfixed by his saddle stirr

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY, (OFF-SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Bob wanted to know could he ride with us next time we took on a savings bank or a railroad. CHARLEY continues hopefully: 1

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Bob isn’t much more than a boy to most appearances, but there’s about two tons of sand in him and he'll stand with his shooter when that's what’s called for. And he’s smart too - he’s about as intricate as they come. JESSE materializes, suddenly vivid against the snow:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You‘re forgetting that I’ve already met the kid.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: He surely thinks highly of you.  74

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: All America thinks highly of me.

dialogues.speaker: . CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Still. It’s not like you‘ve got two million names you can snatch out of a sock whenever you need a third man. I mean, who else is there that isn’t already in jail? JESSE sighs:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You're going to try and wear me down on this, aren‘t you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: (smiles) That was my main intention. The two men disappear again into the grey air.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: A note was mailed to Bob Ford with the news that Jesse and Charley would come to Ray County within the next few weeks. Henry Craig enjoined him to return to Richmond and await the arrival of the two. INT. ELIAS’ GROCERY STORE, RICHMOND - DAY BOB is busy with CUSTOMERS. SHERIFF TIMBERLAKE enters, pr once, and then slips into the storeroom. INT. STOREROOM, ELIAS’ GROCERY STORE, RICHMOND - DAY TIMBERLAKE smokes. BOB enters.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Haven‘t seen any sign of him.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF TIMBERLAKE
dialogues.text: Do you know where he’s living? !

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No. TIMBERLAKE sighs.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF TIMBERLAKE
dialogues.text: I can’t guess how he does it, but he’s always knowledgeable about what’s going on. He’ll know you’ve been with me. You ought to take that for granted. And he'll kill you if he gets the chance. BOB scratches at his neck and looks away.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF TIMBERLAKE
dialogues.text: You willing to risk that?  75

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yes I am. BOB fastens his eyes on TIMBERLAKE and all the ingratiati from his face; only longing and misery remain:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’ve been a nobody all my life. I was the baby; I was the one they made the promises to that they never kept. And ever since I can recall it, Jesse James has been as big as a tree. I'm prepared for this, Jim. And I’m going to accomplish it. I know I won’t get but this one opportunity and you can bet your life I’m not going to spoil it. TIMBERLAKE stands and grinds .out his cigarette,

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF TIMBERLAKE
dialogues.text: Capture him if you can when he first comes to meet you. If you can’t do it, wait for your chance. Don’t allow yourself to be found alone with him. And don’t let him get behind you. TIMBERLAKE exits through the loading door. BOB remains standing there. INT. ELIAS’ GROCERY STORE, RICHMOND ~ ANOTHER DAY BOB stands on a wooden stool, stacking ketchup bottles, i apron. The afternoon sun blazes behind JESSE like a halo:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You’ve been chosen. BOB swivels and nearly slips. The color has leached from

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Your brother said that you wanted to join us. But maybe you like this grocery store more than you said you did. BOB looks for a clue from CHARLEY but his brother is fixe store’s entrance, smoking a cigarette. BOB counterfeits b

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I‘ll walk out of this crackerbox without so much as a fare-thee-well. This piddly work is beneath me. He takes off his apron by way of illustration. JESSE smil  76

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So you missed me?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’ve been crying myself to sleep every night. BOB places a note on the counter that reads, ‘Gone fishin rings open the cash register and finds himself impressed:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Good morning. EXT. ELIAS’ GROCERY STORE, RICHMOND - DAY BOB comes outside with carrots for the horses. CHARLEY is the saddle:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Don’t let him see us so much as wink at each other. He's suspicious as a danged coyote, and he don’t trust you one iota.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I guess that makes us even.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: He's already put way Ed Miller. Said so like it was something piddly he'd done. The talk ceases when JESSE comes out. JESSE corrects the black fedora and slips his boot into the stirrup. HE clim saddle and hooks his horse around: EXT. ROAD TO ST. JOSEPH - NIGHT. They ride through a cold rain. In the distance they spot head towards it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSE throws his greatcoat on a pew and lights an altar c carries into the sanctuary. BOB kicks his bedroll flat on the floor and says to CHARL

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: If we’re ever alone for more than a minute, I'd like a chance to speak to you further.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: BOB wakes and sits up. His brother is asleep. JESSE is curled over the Bible like a monk. BOB wanders over to him and sidles into the pew.  77

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Go to the good book when you’re sore distressed and your soul will be comforted. BOB studies JESSE. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You ever give your past life any thought?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don’t get your meaning.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Do you every give any thought to the men you've killed? JESSE shuts the book and rubs a thumb across the two gold black cover. Rainfall is the only noise.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I’ve been forgiven for all that.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You might ‘ve had a good reason for killing them. I don’t know. I’m just saying it must‘ve been like a nightmare for them, and maybe it is for you too, right now.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I’ve already been forgiven. He blows out the candle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLEY sits on a gravestone engraved with the words ‘GON GREATNESS.' BOB ambles up to him with his palms cupping h

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: They gave me ten days.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Arresting him. You and me?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It‘s going to happen one way or another. It’s going to happen, Charley; and it might as well be us who get rich on it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Nobody’s going to get Jesse if he’s still live enough to go for his gun. He can kill ya with every hand.  78

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’1l go alone then. CHARLEY looks at him disparagingly.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: And besides that he’s our friend.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: He murdered Ed Miller. He's going to murder Liddil and Cummins if the chance ever comes. Seems to me Jesse’s riding from man to man, saying goodbye to the gang. Your friendship could put you under the Pansies. CHARLEY looks away.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I'll grind it fine in my mind, Bob. I can’t go any further than that, right now.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You’ll come around.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: You think it’s all made up don’t you. You think everything is just yarns and newspaper stories. It’s BOB’S turn to look away.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: He’s just a human being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the church and discover a furious JESSE.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: From now on you two won’t go anywhere without me! From now on you'll ask for permission; you‘ll ask to be excused!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They approach the rollercoaster of Confusion Hill. BOB lo steep ascent to a high skull of land upon which rests the cottage.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Jesse finally come up with a Place to match his prominence.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I could mow down a thousand scalawags with no more than a thousand cartridges. I'l] never be surprised by anything again.  79

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSE climbs off his saddle and accepts his son in his ar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB and JESSE enter. ZEE JAMES backs from the stove, sees winces.

dialogues.speaker: ZEE
dialogues.text: You never mentioned Bob would be here.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Maybe he was saving it as a pleasant surprise. MARY is submerged in the woman’s skirt, glowering at BOB. girl’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: ZEE
dialogues.text: You’ve got two cousins for company now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSE, on the sofa, weds his fingers ovér his stomach and eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: How it will be is we'll leave here next Monday afternoon and ride down to Platte City.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: How far is that from Kansas City? Something in BOB'S enquiry makes JESSE resistant and he a the question:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Platte City’s thirty miles south. You and me and Charley will sleep in the woods overnight and strike the Wells Bank sometime before the court recesses.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (a little too insistent) What time will that be exactly?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You don’t need to know that. BOB scrawls on the floorboards with his finger and JESSE sit.  80

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You know I feel comfortable with your brother. Hell, he’s ugly as sin and he smells like a skunk and he's so ignorant he couldn’t drive nails in the snow, but he’s sort of easy to be around. I can’t say the same for you, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to hear you say that. JESSE is silent a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You_know how it is when you're with your girlfriend and the moon is out and you know she wants to be kissed even though she never said so?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You’re giving me signs that grieve my soul and make me wonder if your mind’s been changed about me.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do? Swear my good faith on the bible? CHARLEY enters with the firewood to see JESSE glowering a great heat in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: You two having a spat?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I was getting ready to be angry. JESSE smiles and reaches out to coddle BOB’S neck.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Sit over here closer, Kid. BOB vacillates a little, then scooches over, smirking at with shyness. JESSE massages BOB‘S neck and shoulders, co that all is forgiven.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You'll stay with the animals, Charley, and The Kid and I will walk into the bank just before noon. Bob will move the cashier over away from the shotgun under the counter and he’ll tell the man to open the vault. They’11 finagle about time locks and so on and I’ll creep up behind that cashier and cock his chin back like so..  81 JESSE snaps BOB’S skull back and slashes a skinning knife throat. BOB is incapacitated by panic. JESSE is terrifyin

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I’ll say, ‘How come an off-scouring of creation like you is still sucking air when so many of mine are in coffins?’ BOB‘S eye lolls to the blade.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I’ll say, ‘How'd you reach your twentieth birthday without leaking out all over your clothes?’ And if I don’t like his attitude, I’ll slit that phildoodle so deep he‘ll flop on the floor like a fish, Then JESSE retracts the blade and shoves BOB rudely forwa temper abruptly alters and he slaps both knees gleefully,

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I could hear your gears grinding rrr, rrr, rrr, and your little motor wondering, ‘My Gosh, what’s next, what's happening to me?’ You were precious to behold, Bob. You were white as spit in a cotton field. BOB examines his neck with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You want to know how that feels? Unpleasant. I honestly can’t recommend it.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: And Charley looked striken!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I was!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: ‘This is plumb unexpected!’ old Charley was thinking, ‘This is done ruint my day!’ JESSE laughs and laughs, and when at last the two laugh w adopts a scolding look and slams out of the room. INT. CHILDREN’S ROOM, HOUSE ON THE HILL - NIGHT JESSE sleeps on the twin bed. BOB on his bedroll.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: Jesse slept with Bob in the children’s room that night and Bob remained awake. He could see that there was a gun on the nightstand, he could imagine it’s cold nickel inside his grip, it’s two pound weight reached out and aimed, but he couldn't even maneuver toward it, it was like a name he couldn’t remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82 Tt was if some spell had rendered him meek, infirm, confounded. He could contrive many ways of snaring Jesse; he could invent a thousand deaths; but Bob feared it would always come to this, he would see a chance and then he’d speculate on it’s consequences, he would ponder each option and particular and soon the opportunity would pass away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB, with baited breath, watches through the doorway: JESSE stands naked in a laundry boiler wringing a washclo skull. He’s wracked by a coughing fit. He seems old, prem decrepit, the scars on his body stand out red as slaughte BOB’S hand moves to the granddaddy Colt that’s strapped t But that’s all, he can’t bring himself to unsnug the weap After a long beat, JESSE says:

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Go away.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It never crossed your mind that I was here and it’s been nigh on three minutes at least.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You sure of that? Maybe I was fooling you. Maybe we’re playing cat and mouse.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’ve never seen you without your guns neither. JESSE tows a towel off a chair and reveals, almost incide twelve inch Remington revolver on the seat.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Isn’t no one could sneak up on Jesse James, is the way it used to be.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: And now you think you know otherwise, maybe that’s just what I wanted.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’m just making fun is all, you understand. I wouldn’t dream of mocking you or causing you any ill feelings.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I can’t figure it out: do you want to be like me, or do you want to be me?

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: So it went:  83

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSE around the house, images scored to the Narrator’s v music:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: Jesse was increasingly cavalier, merry, moody, fey, unpredictable. He was sick with rheums and aches and lung congestions, he tilted against chairs and counters and walls, in cold weather he limped with a cane. His clever mind was often in conflict, insomnia stained his eye sockets like soot. He counteracted the smell of neglected teeth with licorice and candies, he browned his graying hair with dye, he camouflaged his depressions and derangements with masquerades of extreme cordiality, courtesy, and goodwill toward others:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

He could be a glib and even grandiloquent speaker, but writing was agony for him: the right words seemed to disappear whenever he grasped a pencil, plus he was hampered by the grim recognition that he really had nothing to say. The government’s sort of run me ragged, you see. I‘m going the long way around the barn to say I’ve been feeling cornered and just plain ornery of late and I‘d be pleased if you'd accept the gun as my way of apologizing.

I go on journeys out of my body and look at my red hands and my mean face and I wonder about that man who’s gone so wrong: Why all that killing and evil behavior? I've been becoming a problem to myself. I figure if I can get you right I’1l be just that much closer to me. BOB looks at the man in bewilderment and can’t find the w answer, so he says:

His fingers skittered over his ribs to construe the scars where Jesse was twice shot. He manufactured a middle finger that was missing the top two knuckles. He imagined himself at thirty-four. He imagined himself in a coffin. He considered possibilities and everything wonderful that could come true. INT.
