dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please don’t put this in the paper.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: I’m afraid that’s my job. DR. HEDDENS enters.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HEDDENS
dialogues.text: What's your name, Madame?

dialogues.speaker: 2EE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Howard.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HEDDENS
dialogues.text: Is that your husband?  101 She nods.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HEDDENS
dialogues.text: Do you know who killed him?

dialogues.speaker: ZEE
dialogues.text: Our two cousins, the Johnsons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARSHAL CRAIG enters with BOB and CHARLEY. JOHN LEONARD i outside the master bedroom door - discretely recording ZE conversation with HEDDENS. The City Marshal crosses over reporter and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL CRAIG
dialogues.text: Do you know who these boys say that man is?

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Someone named Howard.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL CRAIG
dialogues.text: They claim its Jesse James.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Go on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARSHAL CRAIG sits on the bed and takes ZEE’S hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL CRAIG
dialogues.text: Mrs. Howard? The boys who have killed your husband are here. They tell me your husband is Jesse James.

dialogues.speaker: ZEE
dialogues.text: You don’t mean they’ve come back! She slumps against his shoulder, weeping.

dialogues.speaker: -MARSHAL CRAIG
dialogues.text: You know, it would be a lot more restful for your soul if you'd speak the truth. The public would think mighty highly of you; your children wouldn't ever again want for anything. She rubs her eyes with her sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: ZEE
dialogues.text: T want to go see him.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL CRAIG
dialogues.text: How’s that?

dialogues.speaker: ZEE
dialogues.text: I want to see my husband.  102

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL CRAIG
dialogues.text: dust lean your weight on me. The two walk into the sitting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB shrinks back when he sees ZEE and CHARLEY moves to th

dialogues.speaker: ZEE
dialogues.text: You cowards! You snakes! How could you kill your friend? CHARLEY slouches outside and BOB follows, clapping the sc shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SMALL BOY runs down the street yelling:

dialogues.speaker: SMALL BOY
dialogues.text: It’s Jesse James! Jesse James! Jesse James! The crowd ogles them. LEONARD approaches.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: You mean that really is Jesse James?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Isn't that what we’ve been saying since we come?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Have someone twist off that gold ring on his finger. You’ll find a script with the name Jesse James inside. .

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Why’d you kill him? ' Bop Say: we wanted to rid the country of a bloodthirsty outlaw.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: (smiles) You should mention the reward too.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: You shot him for money?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Only ten thousand dollars! BOB scowls at this.  103 I‘1l mention that you are young but gritty.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: We are all grit. You never expected to see Jesse's carcass in St. Joe, did you? We thought we'd create a sensation by putting him away. EXT. HOUSE ON THE HILL — LATER. The body is carried and placed in a glass-sided carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage is followed down the hill by a PROCESSION of including ZEE JAMES. EXT. YARD, HOUSE ON THE HILL — DAY. SNOOPS and ONLOOKERS swarm around the cottage, viewing wh can through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEOPLE investigate the stables, appraising the horses. Th whatever they can fit up their sleeves; horseshoes, hamme

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE move people back from the house. They nail the win shut. In amongst all the bustle an ONLOOKER moves over to TIM a the boy as if they know each other.

dialogues.speaker: ONLOOKER
dialogues.text: So you're Jesse Edwards James. The boy is mystified.

dialogues.speaker: ONLOOKER
dialogues.text: Do you know who Jesse James is? The boy shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ONLOOKER
dialogues.text: Do you know what your father’s name was?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Daddy. The ONLOOKER laughs. INT. SEIDENFADEN UNDERTAKING — DAY  104 JESSE'S body is strapped to a board with ropes. The board nearly vertical and a camera lens uncapped. A room full o CORRESPONDENTS wait for the exposure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REPORTERS follow the PHOTOGRAPHER as he carries the photo plate back to the studio. INSERT: JESSE'S REQUIEM PHOTOGRAPH DEVELOPING.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: The resulting prints sold for two dollars a piece INSERT: MAGAZINE COVERS come off a PRINTING PRESS NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) and were the models for the lithographed covers on a number of magazines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign is hung announcing departure times to St. Joseph. NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) Railway companies had by then rather gleefully scheduled special coaches that would carry the inquisitive to the city at greatly reduced rates;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CROWDS make the journey up Confusion Hill. NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) Soon a thousand strangers were making spellbound pilgrimages to the cottage

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) or were venerating the iced remains in Seidenfaden‘s cooling room. ZEE JAMES sits catatonically in a chair, unmindful of the visitors, merely staring at the slain man. Move in on JESSE. NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) The man who offered thirty thousand dollars for the body of Charles Guiteau sent a telegram to City Marshal Enos Craig offering fifty thousand for the body of Jesse Woodson James so that he could go around the country with it, or at least sell it to P. T. Barnum for his ‘Greatest Show on Earth.’  105

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Action as per voice-over: ) NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) Reporters roamed the city, gathering anecdotes and apocrypha, garnering interviews with the principals. Studies showed that real Estate values in Missouri would increase by thirty-three percent with the removal of the outlaw, and one reporter noted that a man who was selling his farm had already raised the price by five hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Action as per voice-over: )

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jacob Spencer, the man who owned the St. Joseph News, went to his library late that afternoon and began seven nights work on what would become The Life and Career of Frank and Jesse James, INT. BOOKSTORE, COMMERCIAL DISTRICT, ST. JOSEPH - pay (Action as per voice-over: ) NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) a two hundred-page book that sold out as soon as it reached the stores on April 12". Five hundred thousand copies would have been needed to meet the demand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Action as per voice-over:) A NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) A man crept into the cottage that night and cut out a swatch of the bloodstained carpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Action as per voice-over: )

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The next afternoon he was in Chicago selling square inches of the material for five dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: we’ 106 Rain. ZERELDA SAMUELS steps off the train and is greeted throng awaiting her on the platform. She moves in their m Amazon queen - accepting solace and sympathy and sprays o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZERELDA totters as she walks to the stone slab on which h son sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (OFF-SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Can you identify this man as Jesse Woodson James?

dialogues.speaker: ZERELDA
dialogues.text: Yes, it's my son; would to God that it were not. She caresses his cold cheek and cries:

dialogues.speaker: ZERELDA
dialogues.text: O, Jesse! Jesse! Why have they taken you from me? 0, the miserable traitors! As the grief stricken mother is led away, a PHOTOGRAPHER

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: Another photograph was taken of the renowned American bandit constricted in his small walnut coffin. INSERT: this new image of JESSE, followed by the HISTORIC to which he’s compared: NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D)) and it was this shot that was most available in sundries stores and apothecaries, to be viewed in a stereoscope along with the Sphinx, the Taj Mahal, the Catacombs of Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain makes slime of the streets. Yet more than 400 MOURNE the express company wagon that carries the iron casket to and St. Joseph depot. MRS. SAMUELS, MRS. JAMES, and the Two CHILDREN follow in hackney. SHERIFF TIMBERLAKE, HENRY CRAIG, and VARIOUS DEPUTIES and CORRESPONDENTS come after them in carriages festooned wit ribbons and bows. CROWDS line the sidewalk, under wet umbrellas or with hai against their skulls. A CRACKPOT raises a purse pistol and fires at MRS. SAMUEL  107 HENRY CRAIG and another MAN leap from their carriage and drunk into an alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here they beat him roundly and sprawl him into the gutter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THOUSANDS fence the railroad line, removing their hats as passes by. The Coffin is lashed to the rear Platform. SHE T: sits upon it, smoking a pipe.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND MARTIN, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Man that is born of woman is of a few days, and full of trouble. He cometh forth like a flower, and is cut down: he fleeth as a shadow and continueth not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VAST NUMBER is gathered in the yard. The open casket rests on chairs under the shade of the co tree.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND MARTIN, (CONTINUED)
dialogues.text: Lord make me to know mine end and the measure of my days; that I may know how frail I am. Behold thou hast made my days asa handbreadth; and mine age is nothing before thee: verily every man-at his best state is altogether vanity. We get our last glimpse of JESSE as the casket is covered shut. On the lid is a silver Plate with the name ‘Jesse J out in German Gothic lettering. ZEE and ZERELDA are overmastered by grief and throw thems casket, ZERELDA screaming:

dialogues.speaker: . ZERELDA
dialogues.text: How can I stand it? How can I stand it? How can I stand it?

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0O)
dialogues.text: Zerelda Samuels insisted that the casket be reopened to make certain that her son’s arms and legs had not been sawn off and replaced with limbs of wax. SHERIFF TIMBERLAKE goes dutifully for a screwdriver. NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) But Reverend Martin soothed the woman with practiced words about a calculus in heaven that adjusts for our privations and compensates for our losses.
108 The casket is jarringly lowered on ropes as those gathere Will Wait Till Jesus Comes’

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: INT. ALEX LOZO’S PHOTOGRAPHIC STUDIO - DAY BOB sits for a studio Portrait. He poses on a staircase w Peacemaker artificially rested on his left thigh. A CROWD attend him.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: How do you feel, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Bully.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: You‘re right handed ain’t ya, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Then why have you got the gun in your left?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Jesse was left-handed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB looks impossibly young, like a grocery clerk accident with a pistol in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: He could still smell the gunpowder on his fingers, could still feel the jolt of the gun going off. But that was all. He'd seen no Phantoms. Listened to no incorporeal voices. Was subjected to no nightmares. He was asked if he was afraid of reprisals by Frank James but revenge was not a worry really; it was if no person could harm him once Jesse was underground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 109 We are behind an actor silhouetted by footlights:

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR
dialogues.text: Hello, here! The surrender of Dick Liddil! Young man, I thought you told me you didn’t know that Dick had surrendered. PAN to reveal BOB: He’s groomed as a European Prince, and glued-on mustache:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You mean he did? I didn’t know! FRONT ANGLE: BOB and CHARLEY are on a stage: The set behi resembles the sitting room of the cottage on Confusion Hi re-sticks his moustache and continues his bad impersonati Well, it’s very strange. He surrendered three weeks ago and you was right there in the neighborhood. It looks fishy.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR., (V/O)
dialogues.text: It was widely felt that Bob possessed some acting talent and Charley not a jot: CHARLEY takes off his revolvers and flings them onto the voice yells for the balcony:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: In case you’re wondering why I took my guns off, it’s because I might want to walk in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: Charley was only expected not to slouch or mutter and to transport his sicknesses to the alley before letting them go. CHARLEY’S fetches a feather duster and flags it towards a painting of the death of Julius Caesar:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: That picture’s awful dusty! BOB rises surreptitiously from his chair. CHARLEY flicks BOB rests his hand on his gun and turns to the audience:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Up to that moment the thought of killing him had never entered my mind, but as he stood there, unarmed, it came to me suddenly, ‘Now or never is your chance. If you don’t get him now, he’ll get you tonight.’ BOB raises his gun. Some in the audience stir with anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 110 BOB lets the hammer snap and a charge of gunpowder explod great noise on the stage. The audience gasps. CHARLEY reels on the chair, claps his Palms to his chest unauthentically to the floor. A GIRL playing Mrs. James runs onto stage from the right herself a blood-curdling scream. The house lights dim to darkness. Then rise on a stage wh only Robert Ford. He slings his gun and proclaims with gr

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: That is how I killed Jesse James. The curtain rings down to magnanimous applause. INT. MANHATTAN RESTAURANT - NIGHT. BOB, dressed in fine clothes, eats in an elegant restaura over by PRETTY TEENAGED dancing girls. They are a rowdy g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIRLS approach BOB and his DATE at the seashore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GROUP of PEOPLE approach BOB in a hotel lobby, wanting hand. Over these images we hear the narrator:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: By October of 1883, Bob Ford could be identified correctly by more citizens than could the president of the United States. He Was as renowned at twenty as Jesse was after fourteen years of Grand Larceny. In an age where the average wage was twelve cents an hour, Bob was making fifty dollars a Performance, so he could easily think himself rich. INT. CHARLEY’S HOTEL ROOM, MANHATTAN - NIGHT CHARLEY, looking harried and hollow eyed and lonely. Surr occult paraphernalia.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: Charley was increasingly superstitious, increasingly subject to the advice of gypsies who promised to cure his miseries with green teas, pipe smoke, Poultices, even jolts of electricity cranked into his wrists with a magnet generator.  111

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLEY has joined BOB and one of his GIRLFRIENDS for din whispers into the girl’s ear:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I know exactly who you're working for. You won’t get your hooks into me. The GIRLFRIEND is disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: He compared all females unfavorably to Mrs. Zee James, whom he spoke of as certain priests might the Madonna, INT. CHARLEY’S HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT CHARLEY writes:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0 CONT'D)
dialogues.text: and composed long, soul describing letters to her, begging her forgiveness, none of which he mailed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Details of the performance: CHARLEY’S walk, his mouth, hi gestures.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: Something began to change in Charley's stage portrayal of Jesse: his limp seemed more practiced, his high voice was spookily ~ similar to the man’s, his newly suggested dialogue was analogous to a script Jesse might have originated. BOB'S performance is enhanced too; by very real alarm at

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: Too many gunshots on the stage and too many resignations to Bob's betrayal were separating the Ford Brothers as Charley accepted the obligation of personifying Jesse James. CLOSE on CHARLEY/JESSE looking antagonistically at BOB.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: He began to look at his younger brother with spite, as if he suspected that in some future performance he might present himself to a live cartridge in Robert Ford’s gun. A disturbed and shaken BOB shoots CHARLEY/JESSE yet again

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 112 BOB is drunk, wrung out and disheveled. A SINGER tunes hi begins to play:

dialogues.speaker: SINGER
dialogues.text: Jesse James was a man who killed many men/He robbed the Glendale train/He stole from the rich and he gave to the poor/he’d a hand and a heart and a brain. The SINGER begins to stroll the room: coming so near BOB to pull back his legs to let him pass. SINGER (CONT’D) Oh Jesse had a wife to mourn for his life/three children, they were brave/But that dirty little coward that shot Mister Howard has laid Jesse James in his grave. BOB works at registering no change in expression. SINGER (CONT’D) It was Robert Ford, that dirty little coward/I wonder how does he feel?/For he ate of Jesse's bread/and he slept in Jesse's bed/ Then he laid Jesse James in his grave. Finally BOB can stand it no longer. He takes out his gun the floor. The noise is deafening. Everyone turns to BOB_ that follows. BOB lurches slowly to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (swaying drunk) I’m Robert Ford. He flings his pistol at the SINGER and tilts slightly fro

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You gonna fight me, see who the coward is?

dialogues.speaker: SINGER
dialogues.text: I ain’t gonna fight you, boy. You get on outta here.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: MAN AT THE RAIL
dialogues.text: Sleep it off. Someone slaps Bob on the back, sending him a step or two regains himself.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Any you wanna fight me? Huh? Who's it gonna be?  113 They look at him silently. Watch as he slips on peanut sh up on the floor, tears glinting in his eyes. He gets to h sways for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SALOONKEEPER
dialogues.text: Get on home now, son. Go on! Get yourself outta my place.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, BOWERY STREET
dialogues.text: BOB wakes with a dog licking his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A voice comes from the dark beyond the footlights:

dialogues.speaker: HECKLER, (UNSEEN)
dialogues.text: Murderer! Cur! BOB strides towards the insults.

dialogues.speaker: HECKLER, (UNSEEN)
dialogues.text: Coward! BOB shields his eyes from the glare, searching for his an the large audience:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You want to investigate my courage? Do you? The HECKLER stands in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: HECKLER
dialogues.text: Coward!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB’S clothes are shredded and he’s covered in blood from as he’s shackled by POLICEMEN.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: You may be the Ford brothers or the James Brothers but you cahnt drink blood in Boston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ‘sold out’ sticker is plastered over the playbill for I James. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 114 BOB stands silhouetted on stage while a great crowd hisse and pelts him with garbage. When he uneasily raises his g CHARLEY/JESSE they riot: Surging over the footlights, swa destroying the set.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: By his own approximation, Bob assassinated Jesse James over eight hundred times; he suspected no one in history had ever so often or so publicly recapitulated an act of betrayal, and he imagined that no degree of grief or penitence could change the country’s ill regard for him. He thought about committing suicide, but decided even that would be judged just one more act of cowardice. EXT. TRAIN STATION, KANSAS CITY - pay BOB steps off the train. He is going on 22. He's dapper, Physically strong, comparatively rich, and psychologicall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN crosses the street to spit on hin.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: He thought, at his angriest, about visiting the kin of Jesse’s slaughtered victims: Mrs. William Westfall in Plattsburg, the Wymore family in Clay County, perhaps even Mrs. Joseph Heywood in Northfield, Minnesota. He would go to their homes and give his name as Robert Ford, ‘The man who killed Jesse James.‘ He imagined they would be grateful to him. EXT. SAMUEL’S FARM — NIGHT BOB sneaks up on the SAMUEL'S HOMESTEAD. NARRATOR (V/O CONT‘D) But in actuality Bob made only one irregular journey and that one was to Kearney, Missouri. BOB stands before the nine foot monument under the coffee runs his fingers over the inscription: In Loving Remembrance

dialogues.speaker: JESSE W. JAMES
dialogues.text: Died April 3, 1882 Murdered By a Traitor and Coward Whose Name Is Not Worthy To Appear Here. Hold on BOB.  115

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: INT. CHARLEY’S ROOM - DAY. CHARLEY FORD enters the room and lays down on his bed. He revolver from it’s scabbard and shoots himself through th

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: Charley Ford became all that his countrymen wanted an assassin of Jesse James to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A funeral: The SURVIVING FORDS watch CHARLEY’S COFFIN bei into the ground.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: Except for Bob, the rest of the Fords completed their lifetimes peacefully and disappeared from history.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL'S FARM, (MONTAGE)
dialogues.text: Action as per voice-over:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: Zerelda Samiels remained on the Kearney farm. Her greatest source of income was the twenty- five cent tours of the grounds and rooms, during which she gave gasconades about her slaughtered sons. She would cozen many of her guests, make them feel especially privileged, and at last agree to sell them a stone from the grave or, at much greater expense, a worn shoe from one of the James boy's steeds. (These we see he her buying from a BLACKSMITH by the whee The stones are shoveled from Clear Creek and spread on th

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: She outlived three husbands and four of the eight children she bore and she showed no signs of sickness when she retired to a pullman sleeper in 1911 and there died of a stroke at the age of eighty-seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZEE JAMES works with a bucket and mop.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: Zee returned to Kansas City in 1882 and worked there as a cleaning woman and seamstress in a manner that many construed as penitent.  116 INT. ZEE’S ROOM - DAY, ZEE, alone.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: She retired from the public eye, shunning reporters, seeking retreat. She felt crippled, forsaken, marooned. Jesse was her vitality, her vigor, her crucial ingredient and she gratefully accepted death in 1900 at the age of fifty-five. INT. MARY JAME'S HOME - DAY. MARY JAMES, now an adult, at dinner with her family.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: Her daughter, Mary, married an affluent farmer and gave birth to three boys ona Property across the road from her father’s birthplace. She called no Particular attention to her heritage and many who knew her when she passed away in 1935 were surprised by her maiden name.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE EDWARDS JAMES, (PHOTO MONTAGE)
dialogues.text: Actual stills of JESSE JNR at various times in his life a the movies described:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: Her brother took great advantage of the name Jesse Edwards James. He played semi- professional baseball, ran a cigar stand, and became an attorney-at-law in Kansas and Los Angeles. When Jesse was twenty-four he wrote the memoir Jesse James My Father; in 1921 he financed and acted in the movie Under the Black Flag, and some years later he was a highly paid technical adviser to Paramount Pictures when they produced their counterfeit Jesse James, starring Tyrone Power. Jesse Edwards James died in California in 1951.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: Alexander Franklin James was in Baltimore when he read about the assassination of Jesse James. FRANK walks past a newspaper stand and sees the headline Jehova.’ ‘Its Jesse, by  117

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: He had spurned his younger brother for being peculiar and temperamental, but once he perceived he’d never see Jesse again, Frank was wrought up, perplexed, despondent. EXT. CENTRAL PARK, NEW YORK - DAY. FRANK, grief-stricken and isolated.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: The East seemed a foreign country to him, and whichever city he visited seemed an uninhabited island without Jesse alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A_CROWD of REPORTERS, OFFICALS and POLICE have gathered t FRANK‘S surrender:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: Frank surrender his arms to governor Crittenden on October 5%, 1882.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to CRITTENDEN) I want to hand over to you my guns which no man has been permitted to touch since 1861, and to say that I am your prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK at parties. CROWDS awaiting his appearance at train etc.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: The government accorded privileges to Prank James; he was given parties, gentile receptions, magnificent presents and accommodations, an opulent coach carried him to his trials in Jackson County; to some it seemed that the State of Missouri had surrendered to Frank James rather than the other way round. INT. COURTROOM - DAY. FRANK in the witness box. We cant hear what he’s saying b is cool and collected.  118

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: He evinced dignity, intelligence, rectitude and sobriety. He represented every quality that gentlemen then were eager to possess. He could speak passable German and French; he could recite one thousand lines of Shakespeare; he was not suspiciously attractive; he had fought on the right side in the Civil war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A jubilant CROWD has gathered. FRANK shakes hands with me JURY.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: So it was that in spite of more than circumstantial evidence linking Frank James to a great many crimes, the man never served a day in the penitentiary.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: He acted as a race starter, a shoe salesman, he accepted tickets at the Standard Theatre in St. Louis, refusing all invitations to see the saucy burlesque show inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK wanders among the gravestones, attended by a REPORT

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: He was a survivor and it made him feel guilty. It seemed to Frank that grace came upon him without merit, that he’d been pardoned without justification or purpose. FRANK squatted at an ill-kept grave. He straightens and r earth from his hands: ‘FRANK ‘Then two shall be in the field; the one shall be taken, and the other left.’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK, nearing the end of his life.  119

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: After his mother’s death he settled once again on the Kearney farm. Here he lived out his days, walking from room to room with tourists, who now paid fifty cents to see the Bible that Jesse read, and one of the guns he shot. Alexander Franklin James died on February 18™ 1915. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are moving behind a man pulling ice in a child’s red w upon a young woman (DOROTHY EVANS) in a long green gown o frills and ruffles.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I was expecting someone old and ugly.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Creede has a supply of them: just who in particular?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: You are Bob Ford? FRONT ANGLE on BOB FORD, now thirty years old.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: And proud of it too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against all odds, BOB has prospered; his Exchange Club is DOROTHY EVANS gives BOB her story:

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I was brought up in an orphanage run by the sisters of Mercy. My only skirt was a flour sack until I married a mining engineer in Denver. He died of pneumonia, though, and desperation has pushed me into the life of a courtesan.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You mean a prostitute. You don’t have to sugar things with me.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I'm not ashamed of it; I just like the word.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’ve got some call for it, if you’re willing.  120

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Could be. She pulls a gold case from her purse and BOB lights her c

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You know who I am? She nods eagerly, like a girl slightly in love with her t

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Bob Ford.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The man who shot Jesse James.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I’ve seen your picture.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: So you were lying.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You said you were expecting someone old and ugly, when you knew just what I looked like.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: (sweet smile) I was making conversation.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: How much of that is true, about the orphanage and the Sisters of Mercy and the mining engineer?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Hardly any. BOB is finding her very engaging: '

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Do you have a given name or do you just generally make something up?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Dorothy.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You can sing though, can’t you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOROTHY sings ‘Only a Bird in a Gilded Cage’ for a packed house  121

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: It was only with Dorothy Evans that Bob spoke revealingly or plainly, and it was with her that he spoke of things he didn’t know he knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB and DOROTHY stroll the snowy streets of Creede. BOB i extraordinary in his dress; a dandy in his gentleman’s cl cane. SHOPKEEPERS and CITIZENS greet him, defer to him. H king in this town. NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) He told her that he had no real memory of the shooting and its aftermath: He could remember lifting the gun that Jesse had given him and then it was Good Friday and he was reading about the funeral proceedings as if they'd happened a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB and DOROTHY are among a crowd of ICE-SKATERS, enjoyin afternoon:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He explained that he'd kept the newspaper clippings from April 1882 and repeatedly Poured over them, each time feeling aped, cruelly maligned by the Robert Ford that the correspondents chose to put into print. On BOB, happy. NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) He was ashamed of his persiflage, his boasting, his pretensions of courage and ruthlessness; he was sorry about his cold- bloodedness, his dispassion, his i: ility to express what he now believed was the case:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOROTHY brings him a beer. NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) That he truly regretted killing Jesse, that he missed the man as much as anybody and wished his murder hadn’t been necessary.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Was it? BOB looks at her without comment.  122

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: How I mean it is: why was it you killed him?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: He was going to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: So you were scared and that’s the only reason? He sips from his beer.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: And the reward money.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Do you want me to change the subject? He looks at her in a calculating way.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Do you know what I expected? Applause. I was only twenty years old then. I couldn’t see how it would look to people. I’ve been surprised by what’s happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD O KELLY comes in and takes a seat at the crowded b He seems to argue with himself before shrugging off his w seems wild, insane, and fifty years old, though he’s only O KELLY unsnugs his gun and jostles through the gambling close on BOB. He pulls up his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE BYSTANDER
dialogues.text: He‘s going to kill you! But BOB only smiles and pretends he’s Jesse as he approac arms outstretched:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Hey! You oughta let bygones be bygones! His congenial grin slows O KELLY just enough to allow BOB cheek and clasp his pistol. He jolts O KELLY awry and sla into the man’s mouth. O KELLY collapses with a split uppe BOB slams his skull with the pistol.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Get out! Get out and don’t you ever set foot in my place again. © KELLY 3 wuss 2 will

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 123 BOB stamps the floor and O KELLY shies, cringing under hi BOB laughs and rejoins the corner table of gamblers. They with approval. DOROTHY crosses to him, and he says to her

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It just goes on and on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOAPY SMITH, a confidence man, sitting with his BODYGUARD KELLY get back into his coat, and exiting into the snow s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOAPY SMITH catches up to KELLY under an arc lamp. Blood off the man’s chin and he spits out chips of teeth like g

dialogues.speaker: O KELLY
dialogues.text: Second time I’ve tried to get that son of a bitch. SOAPY wings an arm around the man’s neck.

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY SMITH
dialogues.text: Why don’t we see if we can’t get you stitched up. INT. BOB & DOROTHY’S APARTMENT - DAY BOB sits in a green leather chair while SOAPY SMITH Prowl apartment with a cigar and brandy snifter, appraising obj room.

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY SMITH
dialogues.text: So, you know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’ve heard stories; not that I put much stock in what those goddam newspapers say.

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY SMITH
dialogues.text: You couldn’t, could you. 1

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Meaning what? SOAPY ignores that, his attention on the Paperweight he’s

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Just. what was it you had in mind with this meeting? Outside of making an inventory of all my worldly goods. SOAPY resettles in a chair and swishes brandy from cheek

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY SMITH
dialogues.text: Do you know what you shoulda done about Jesse?  124

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No; why don’t you tell me.

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY SMITH
dialogues.text: (smiles) I will then. one night you oughta gone out and sorta lagged behind old Jess on your horse. You get your gun out and yell his name and once he spins around, bang! You coulda said you two had an argument and shot it out and you come out the victor. I guess you never thought of it though.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I wasn’t big enough.

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY SMITH
dialogues.text: You sure done the wrong thing, killing the man with his wife and kids close by, and his guns off and, well, you know what you did. You oughta said you were sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I figure if I’m sorry or not, that’s my own business.

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY SMITH
dialogues.text: Don‘t matter! You ought to apologize and give | ‘em what they want! A man looks at Bob Ford now and you know what he sees? He sees pride and greed and no regrets.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’m not begging for forgiveness. I’m going to get people to respect me for my accomplishments, just like Jesse did. SOAPY scratches his beard.

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY SMITH
dialogues.text: Do you know Joe Simmons?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’ve said pleased-to-meetcha.

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY SMITH
dialogues.text: Joe and me have been talking about you and Creede and how things are and we thought maybe we'd begin a saloon and gambling hall like yours. We figure maybe we‘ll get rich by Pushing de booze over de boards.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Do you think there’s much call for another saloon? They say there’s one for every five men as it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to get in and make the others get out.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Just out of curiosity: how are you going to do that?

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY SMITH
dialogues.text: My gang, Bob! I’m going to be the government! I’m going to run things around here! Y’all come over to my way of thinking or, bingo, out you go!

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I forgot how to get scared ten years ago.

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY SMITH
dialogues.text: I figured that too. SOAPY gets up:

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY SMITH
dialogues.text: You and me, we're exactly alike. If the time comes for killing Robert Ford, I guess you'll know what I’1l do.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Like I said: Itve already been as scared as I’ll ever be. SOAPY exits and BOB goes over to the windows that look ov He sees SOAPY laughing with his BODYGUARDS as he slogs th Snow. He sees SHOPKEEPERS greeting the man and giving way sidewalk. He slumps against the wall. EXT. BOB & DOROTHY’S APARTMENT - DAY A slaughtered cat is nailed to his door, along with a not ‘Get out of town.’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Action as per voice-over:)

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: Even as he circulated his saloon he knew that the smiles disappeared when he passed by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Action as per voice-over:)  126 NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) He received so many menacing letters in the mail that he could read them without any reaction except curiosity. INT. BOB & DOROTHY’S APARTMENT - DAY {Action as per voice-over:) NARRATOR (V/O CONT’D) He kept to his apartment all day, flipping over playing cards, looking at his destiny in every King and Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire grows like ivy over the wooden walls. Wallpaper peel floors. Glassware explodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A conflagration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grand opening. Music. REVELERS spilling out onto the st

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: Bob called his fifth saloon the Omaha Club and the grand opening was such a success that. Nellie Russell sought Mr. Ford out, saying that she’d accept any job with him, even one as a prostitute:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB and MISS NELLIE RUSSELL stand at the top of Rio Grand sees the lights of cooking fires in the foothills. He hea uproar of the OMAHA CLUB.

dialogues.speaker: NELLIE RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I could‘ve recognized you anywhere. You‘re just like your photograph.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’m not just like the boy in that photograph, though. I’ve aged.

dialogues.speaker: NELLIE RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I thought you were so daring and romantic. I thought you were the most glamorous man alive.  127

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get along fine with girls of ten, it’s when they grow to be eleven or twelve that I'ma — goner. She giggles, and then her thoughts must anguish her, for quiet and grips her shawl around her. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: NELLIE RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I guess an angel must be flying over us. BOB makes no comment.

dialogues.speaker: NELLIE RUSSELL
dialogues.text: The mountains are so steep everywhere! It’s like you’re inside an envelope!

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You were going to ask me what Jesse was like.

dialogues.speaker: NELLIE RUSSELL
dialogues.text: How'd you know?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: They always do. BOB takes MISS RUSSELL’S elbow and they begin the descend to the OMAHA CLUB.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: “ Jesse James was bigger than you can imagine, ~ and he was hungry all the time. He ate all the food in the dining room and he ate all the plates and the glasses and the light off the candles and the air out of your lungs and the thoughts right out of your mind. You'd go to him, wanting to be with him, wanting to be like him, and you'd always come away missing something. BOB looks at the girl with anger, and of course she is lo peculiarly at him.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: So now you know why I shot him. MISS RUSSELL sights the ground as they walk, and when she there is grief in her voice:

dialogues.speaker: NELLIE RUSSELL
dialogues.text: My father would read to us about it from the “newspapers he bought. He said we were living through a great moment in history. He thought you'd done the world a big favor.  128

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: On your right is the Leadville Headquarters. Over there is the smithy’s shop. You can't see them from here but I’ve got four green tents behind the club and men go in and out all night.

dialogues.speaker: NELLIE RUSSELL
dialogues.text: You're making me sad. He can see by the lights in her eyes that the girl is cry

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You ought to go back. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Don’t work for me.

dialogues.speaker: NELLIE RUSSELL
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You've got your dignity yet; I wouldn't give it away for money. INT. EDWARD O KELLY’S CABIN - NIGHT A rapping at the door. EDWARD O'KELLY rises from his bed figure in an orange beaver coat. O KELLY sits and scratch

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY
dialogues.text: You and wash soap ought to meet once or twice.

dialogues.speaker: O KELLY
dialogues.text: You woke me.

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY
dialogues.text: You hear that music? SOAPY lights a cigar. There’s the distant sound of a pian

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY
dialogues.text: It‘s the Omaha Club. Bob Ford’s having his grand opening tonight. O KELLY spits.

dialogues.speaker: O KELLY
dialogues.text: I’1l give him a grand opening one of these days. SOAPY scratches his head.  129

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY
dialogues.text: I come to tell ya regarding that. He’s got on one of his periodicals and he’s puffed himself up to say he’s going to kill Ed Kelly on sight.

dialogues.speaker: O KELLY
dialogues.text: Why, that son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY
dialogues.text: And Bob’s one of the most plausible talkers I ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: O KELLY
dialogues.text: I expect he’1l ask me to turn my back first. SOAPY sucks on his cigar and looks at it as he blows smok

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY
dialogues.text: You oughta do something.

dialogues.speaker: O KELLY
dialogues.text: I‘1l go down there now and give him a straightening.

dialogues.speaker: SOAPY
dialogues.text: I’d give it till around afternoon if I were you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The body of MISS NELLIE RUSSELL is brought into town on a by RAILROAD CREWMEN. The wagon passes by DOROTHY EVANS. INT. BOB & DOROTHY’S APARTMENT - DAY BOB is dressed in his gentleman’s clothes, affixing his c opal stick pin. DOROTHY enters.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: You know that girl you were talking to about a job? She went and killed herself.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (sighs) Oh, God. He sits on the end of the bed and gazes at nothing for so

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: You were right not to give her a job, Bob. BOB gets up and walks out of the room without saying anyt on DOROTHY.  130

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: Dorothy Evans would be married in 1900 toa Mr. James Feeney of Durango, Colorado. She would adopt two daughters, and, according to gossip, she would mistreat them. Her legal marriage would be joyless and one Sunday morning she would get into her green wedding dress, telling her daughters she was going to take a nap. She would then pour chloroform into a cloth and press it to her nose until she perished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB skims the mail and collects his subscription newspape

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD O KELLY trudges towards a rendezvous.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: Edward 0. Kelly came down from Bachelor at 1 p.m. on the 8". He had no grand scheme, no strategy, no agreement with higher authorities, nothing beyond a vague longing for glory and a generalized wish for revenge against Robert Ford. KELLY is joined by JOE DUVAL, who carries a twin-barrel, shotgun. They repair themselves to a machinist’s shop. . INT, MACHINIST’S SHOP - DAY Here they collect metal shavings and, using a paper funne first the right shotgun barrel and then the left.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/0)
dialogues.text: Edward O. Kelly would be ordered to serve a life sentence in the Colorado penitentiary for second degree murder. Over seven thousand signatures would eventually be gathered on a petition asking for Kelly‘s release, and in 1902 Governor James B. Orman would pardon the man. He would write gruesome letters to Bob Ford's widow, but otherwise do nothing except get arrested on charges of vagrancy and ramble from one insignificant town to the next, before his death in 1904.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLA MAE WATERSON pours jiggers of whisky to a group of m removes his suit coat and hangs it on a nail. He then rem cartridge belt, winds it around his gun and snugs this ag register.  131

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t be wearing that stickpin again, Bob. Opals are unlucky.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: My luck isn’t very good as it is. I guess an opal couldn’t change it much.

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: I hear you. EXT. RIO GRANDE AVENUE to INT. OMAHA CLUB - DAY We follow O KELLY as he makes his way up the street to th

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: There would be no eulogies for Bob, no photographs of his body would be sold in sundries stores, no people would crowd the streets in the rain to see his funeral cortege, no biographies would be written about him, no children named after him, no one would ever pay twenty-five cents to stand in the rooms he grew up in. O KELLY enters with his shotgun raised and catches the ma Jesse James laughing with ELLA MAE WATERSON and giving hi street.

dialogues.speaker: O KELLY
dialogues.text: Hello, Bob! BOB turns to the greeting and we freeze on his face.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V/O)
dialogues.text: The shotgun would ignite, and Ella May would scream, but Robert Ford would only lay on the floor and look at the ceiling, the light going out of his eyes before he could find the right words.
